Name: Aguas Arriba Lodge
Description: Only accessible by boat or a 3 hour hike through the surrounding forest, Aguas Arriba is a secluded lodge on the shore of Lago del Desierto. The lodge has a homely feel with lovely hosts and only 6 rooms, and it is a wonderful place to relax whilst enjoying spectacular views of Mt. Fitz Roy, Mt. Torre and Glaciar Vespignani. Excursions on offer include trekking, boat trips and fly fishing. See our page on Aguas Arriba Lodge to find out more.

Name: Aguja Pollone
Description: Aguja Pollone, meaning the Pollone Needle, is a granite spire which can be seen in front of Mount Fizt Roy from the viewpoint at Laguna Pollone, just off the Electrico Valley.
Description (with html): Aguja Pollone, meaning the Pollone Needle, is a granite spire which can be seen in front of Mount Fizt Roy from the viewpoint at Laguna Pollone, just off the Electrico Valley.

Name: Ainsworth Bay
Description: A beautiful isolated bay in the Almirantazgo Sound, Ainsworth Bay is found along the fjords of the Chilean coast and can be visited on board an adventure cruise . At Ainsworth Bay you can see the retreating Marinelli Glacier and watch elephant seals on the beaches. This is a difficult place to reach by any means other than by boat, and it is one of the most pristine and secluded spots to visit in this part of Chilean Patagonia.
Description (with html):

Name: Almirante Marcos A. Zar Airport (REL), Trelew
Description: Trelew is an industrial city, but its airport receives daily flights from Buenos Aeres and it serves Puerto Madryn and the wildlife reserve of Peninsula Valdes.
Description (with html): Trelew is an industrial city, but its airport receives daily flights from Buenos Aeres and it serves Puerto Madryn and the wildlife reserve of Peninsula Valdes.
NEW CUSTOM ADDRESS/WHAT3WORDS: Ruta Nacional N°3 s/n, U9100 Trelew, República Argentina

Name: Altair Winery
Description: Altair vineyard, is located close to the town of Requinoa. The main factors that give character and complexity to their wine are their proximity to the mountains and the cool breezes that come down causing a natural temperature in the vineyard of 25 degrees and up, allowing them to extend the natural maturation of the fruit on the vine.
Description (with html): Altair vineyard, is located close to the town of Requinoa. The main factors that give character and complexity to their wine are their proximity to the mountains and the cool breezes that come down causing a natural temperature in the vineyard of 25 degrees and up, allowing them to extend the natural maturation of the fruit on the vine.

Name: Amalia Glacier
Description: The Amalia or Skua Glacier is found in Bernardo O'Higgins National Park, and comes down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. It is a retreating glacier and is receding at an incredibly fast past compared with other glaciers in the region. This glacier partially surrounds Reclus Volcano and erodes its northern flank. The glacier is accessed by boat or, for the more adventurous explorers, by kayak.

Name: Ancud
Description: The capital of the Island of Chiloe, Ancud is a city which was visited on 28th June 28, 1834 by Charles Darwin during the Second voyage of HMS Beagle. The population here is rural and survives mainly from fishing. Find out about volunteering on a local farm in this region.

Name: Antillanca
Description: A group of stratovolcanoes, the most prominent of which is Volcan Casablanca.
Description (with html): A group of stratovolcanoes, the most prominent of which is Volcan Casablanca.

Name: Antonio Veras Peninsula
Description: A sparsley populated peninsula close to Puerto Natales.
Description (with html): A sparsley populated peninsula close to Puerto Natales.

Name: Aonikenk Trail
Description: The Aonikenk Trail leads across an open landscape with panoramic views, to a collection of Aonikenk Indian paintings on rocks.
Description (with html): The Aonikenk Trail leads across an open landscape with panoramic views, to a collection of Aonikenk Indian paintings on rocks.

Name: Archipeliago Calbuco
Description: A collection of islands in the Reloncavi Sound in Llanquihue province.
Description (with html): A collection of islands in the Reloncavi Sound in Llanquihue province.

Name: Archipielago de los Chonos
Description: This is a collection of islands just South of Chiloe, which can be seen from aboard your ship on an adventure cruise to this region.
Description (with html): This is a collection of islands just South of Chiloe, which can be seen from aboard your ship on an adventure cruise to this region.

Name: Arco Iris Mirador
Description: Lookout point in the Cochamo valley - with wonderful views of the granite mountains. Find out more about this beautiful valley on our Patagonia Chile page.
Description (with html): Lookout point in the Cochamo valley - with wonderful views of the granite mountains. Find out more about this beautiful valley on our Patagonia Chile page.

Name: Awasi Patagonia
Description: The Awasi Patagonia is a luxury lodge, which opened in November 2013, made up from 12 luxury villas on a private reserve, just outside Torres del Paine National Park. Built from locally sourced wood and designed to make the most of the views of the park, the villas include fireplace and outdoor hot tub. Private guide and vehicle are provided for tailor made excursions. The lodge also has a restaurant, exclusively for its guests. >> Read more and check availability for the Awasi Patagonia

Name: Bahia Bustamante
Description: A secluded seaside town with a rich variety of wildlife
Description (with html): A secluded seaside town with a rich variety of wildlife

Name: Bahía Grande
Description: Bahía Grande is a large bay of the Argentine Sea in the Atlantic Ocean, located in the province of Santa Cruz, Argentina.
Description (with html): Bahía Grande is a large bay of the Argentine Sea in the Atlantic Ocean, located in the province of Santa Cruz, Argentina.

Name: Bahia Inutil (King Penguins)
Description: Parque Pinguino Rey is a private nature reserve, whose aim is to preseve the colony of king penguins that reside here. It is the only continental king penguin colony. Trips to see the penguins depart from Punta Arenas, 1 or 2 day trips available.
Description (with html): Parque Pinguino Rey is a private nature reserve, whose aim is to preseve the colony of king penguins that reside here. It is the only continental king penguin colony. Trips to see the penguins depart from Punta Arenas, 1 or 2 day trips available.

Name: Bahía Los Renos
Description: Bahía Los Renos is a remote bay and a complex of cabins located on the shores of Lake Fagnano (also known as Lake Khami) in the province of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina.
Description (with html): Bahía Los Renos is a remote bay and a complex of cabins located on the shores of Lake Fagnano (also known as Lake Khami) in the province of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina.

Name: Bahia Tic-Toc
Description: Found in Corcovado National Park, this unusual part of Patagonia has a flourishing ecosystem that shelters Fiords, bays, rivers, and volcanoes. In Tic-Toc Bay you'll see penguins clustered on small islands, deep blue waters and green forests.
Description (with html): Found in Corcovado National Park, this unusual part of Patagonia has a flourishing ecosystem that shelters Fiords, bays, rivers, and volcanoes. In Tic-Toc Bay you'll see penguins clustered on small islands, deep blue waters and green forests.

Name: Bahia Tunel
Description: Tunel Bay is found at the North West corner of Lago Viedma in Los Glaciares National Park. This is one of the last areas you will reach when trekking the Huemul Circuit, and it is possible to get a vehicle transfer from here back to El Chalten. Boats from here can take you to Glaciar Viedma, and it is possible to fish trout in the bay.
Description (with html): Tunel Bay is found at the North West corner of Lago Viedma in Los Glaciares National Park. Name: Bahia Voces
Description: Bahia Voces or The Bay of Voices lies on the Magellan Straits, around 60 kilometers south of Punta Arenas, beside Puntas Santa Ana and San Juan.
Description (with html): Bahia Voces or The Bay of Voices lies on the Magellan Straits, around 60 kilometers south of Punta Arenas, beside Puntas Santa Ana and San Juan.

Name: Baker River
Description: Chile's most voluminous river, the Baker is famous for its distinctive turquoise blue colour due to glacial sediment. It flows from the enormous General Carrera Lake westwards into the Pacific, reaching the ocean close to the unique and wonderful village of Tortel, a forest village built on stilts. More marvellous photography opportunities await elsewhere with fantastic panoramas all along its course. The Baker River is also nown for fly fishing in particular, as well as the opportunities to descend it by boat. The Baker River is home to an abundance of Rainbow trout, which can be fished from boats or from the riverbanks. The water is crystal clear allowing you to easily observe the trout swimming close by. The Green Baker Lodge is situated by the river and is a comfortable base for fishing and other activities. Unfortunately the Baker is currently under threat from a hydroelectric company. This beautiful river is now home to Conservacion HQ and the Patagonia National Park that the organisation is working hard to create. Find out about volunteering with this organisation on our Volunteer in Patagonia page.

Name: Balmaceda
Description: Close to the Argentine border, Balmaceda lies between Cerro Castillo and Coyhaique. It is only a small town but is home to Aisen region's largest airport.
Description (with html): Close to the Argentine border, Balmaceda lies between Cerro Castillo and Coyhaique. It is only a small town but is home to Aisen region's largest airport.

Name: Balmaceda Airport (BBA)
Description: Near the town of Coyhaique this airport is the access point for Chile's wild and remote Aisen region. It's a small airport with occasional (sometimes daily) flights from Santiago (via Puerto Montt).
Description (with html): Near the town of Coyhaique this airport is the access point for Chile's wild and remote Aisen region. It's a small airport with occasional (sometimes daily) flights from Santiago (via Puerto Montt).

Name: Balmaceda camp
Description: Balmaceda camp is located near to Hosteria Monte Balmaceda on the Serrano River. It is used as an overnight stop for kayaking trips.
Description (with html): Balmaceda camp is located near to Hosteria Monte Balmaceda on the Serrano River. It is used as an overnight stop for kayaking trips.

Name: Balmaceda Glacier
Description: About the Glacier An impressive hanging glacier, it can be found in the southern part of Torres del Paine National Park in Chilean Patagonia - Patagonia's most popular. Unlike other glaciers in this part of Patagonia, this glacier does not come down off the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, but is attached to the similar Serrano Glacier. How to see it: Few people visit this impressive glacier whilst in Torres del Paine in comparison to the number of people that hike to the sprawling Glacier Grey whilst trekking the W Circuit. Kayaking A fantastic way of seeing this glacier is kayaking out of the park on a 2 or 3-day tour of the Rio Serrano and its surrouding picturesque area.Find out more about kayaking in Torres del Paine, and kayaking to glaciers. More Details >>

Name: Bariloche
Description: San Carlos de Bariloche, which comes from the indigenous word 'Vuriloche' meaning "people from behind the mountain", lies on the edge of Lago Nahuel Huapi, a vast, blue lake which is popular with sea-kayakers. Bariloche is the gateway to the Argentinian lake district. Things to do in Bariloche For those looking for some adventure in the winter months, we'd recommend Bariloche's ski resort of Cerro Catedral, 7 miles from town. For some white water rafting, try the Rio Manso which has two sections; Manso Inferior and Manso de la Frontera. Manso Inferior is grade 2-3 and needs about 8 hours to raft. Manso de la Frontera is grade 3-4 and could take a few days to raft. Bariloche's luxury spas and hotels in the hills surrounding the town make the perfect base for day hikes into the Nahuel Huapi National Park (15 miles away in the north-eastern corner of the lake) and for longer mountain biking expeditions. Bariloche's glut of chocolate shops and its sandy beaches attract hoards of Argentinians in the summer months looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. The 'Circuito Chico' offers a leisurely trek and bus ride to spectacular viewpoints just outside Bariloche and, although quite touristy, the circuit is worth doing, in particular taking the ski lift up to the Cerro Campanario viewpoint for spectacular vistas of lakes Trebol and Moreno. Find our more about what to do in Bariloche. Accommodation Whether you want to stay in the middle of the town, or if you want to get out to a lake-side lodges or working estancia, there are plenty of options for you in Bariloche and the surrounding Lake District. Take a look at our list of recommended accommodation in the Lake District.

Name: Bariloche Airport (BRC)
Description: The Bariloche Airport, officially known as San Carlos de Bariloche Airport (also known as Teniente Luis Candelaria Airport), is an international airport serving the city of San Carlos de Bariloche in Argentina.
Description (with html): The Bariloche Airport, officially known as San Carlos de Bariloche Airport (also known as Teniente Luis Candelaria Airport), is an international airport serving the city of San Carlos de Bariloche in Argentina.

Name: Beagle Channel
Description: The Beagle Channel is located in the wild and seemingly inhospitable land of Tierra del Fuego. At it's eastern end, the Beagle Channel forms part of the Chilean-Argentinian border, which was set some hundred years ago. The ownership of the Beagle's three small islands has long been in dispute, but the issue was resolved when the islands were awarded to Chile in 1985.The Beagle Channel is where many Antarctic cruises set sail on their way from the port of Ushuaia all the way down to the South Shetland Islands.It's also a challenging but fun place for kayaking. Kayaking trips tend to focus around Gable Island, where you can paddle to come face to face with sea lion colonies, see penguin rookeries and, if you're lucky, spot whales. Nearby natural landmarks include Mount Darwin, Tierra del Fuego's greatest peak that many climbers attempt to ascend, and Cape Horn. The Beagle Channel's nearest entry point on the Argentinian side is the small port town of Ushuaia, near to where Darwin would have stayed when he visited Tierra del Fuego on board the HMS Beagle in 1831.

Name: Bernado O'Higgins National Park
Description: The largest area of protection in Chile, 35 000 square km. It's neighboured by Torres del Paine and Los Glaciares to its east, the two most popular national parks of Patagonia; and San Rafael National Park to its north. The main gateways to the park are Puerto Natales, Villa O'Higgins, and Tortel. It is one of the few homes left for the Patagonian Huemul. Marine otters and Andean condors are also frequently sighted here.

Name: Buenos Aires
Description: Buenos Aires, the Argentine capital, is where many visitors to the Argentinian part of Patagonia start their trip. Airports Flights from around the world come into the international airport (EZE) just to the South of the city, and the more central domestic airport (AEP) connects Buenos Aires to several airports in Patagonia. We've put together a guide so you can find out about moving between the two airports for connections and what to do in the city while youre there! Things to do The city itself is exciting and vibrant, with plenty of history and sights to discover you'll never be stuck for something to do! Swoop has put together some recommendations of things to do in Buenos Aires, be sure to take a look so you don't miss out!! Accommodation From somewhere to stay for those with a tighter budget to somewhere a bit more special, there are plenty of accommodation offers in Buenos Aires. We have put together a list of our favourites so you can make the most of your stay! Hotels in Buenos Aires >>

Name: Cabanas Aires del Fitz
Description: If you'd like to stay in private accommodation rather than a hotel, Aires del Fitz, with views of Mount Fitz Roy, are the best place in el Chalten. They offer comfortable and warm accommodation, with a bedroom upstairs and living room, kitchen and extra bed downstairs for a reasonable price. In the heart of Chalten and only a 10 minute drive from the start of the trails into Los Glaciares National Park, you can't fault the hospitality of the family that runs them and the accommodation. Find out more and see other hotels in El Chalten.

Name: Cabo Froward
Description: Cabo Froward is the southernmost point of the South American continent.
Description (with html): Cabo Froward is the southernmost point of the South American continent.

Name: Cabo San Pio Lighthouse
Description: Cabo San Pio lighthouse is located on the Mitre Peninsula in Tierra del Fuego. The area is visited by trekkers and, if the weather is good, they can walk to the cape.
Description (with html): Cabo San Pio lighthouse is located on the Mitre Peninsula in Tierra del Fuego. The area is visited by trekkers and, if the weather is good, they can walk to the cape.

Name: Cahuelmo Fjord
Description: A must-see for sea lion colonies and hot springs, this fjord forms part of the vast national park of Pumalin. Cahuelmo is a hidden gem for kayaking in the Chilean Lake District, where the nearest big town is that of Puerto Montt. More about the Lake District >>
Description (with html):
A must-see for sea lion colonies and hot springs, this fjord forms part of the vast national park of Pumalin.

Cahuelmo is a hidden gem for kayaking in the Chilean Lake District, where the nearest big town is that of Puerto Montt.

More about the Lake District >>

Name: Calama
Description: Calama is a city in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile, primarily known as a major mining center and the closest city with an airport to the tourist-famous town of San Pedro de Atacama and the Chuquicamata copper mine.
Description (with html): A City in the Atacama Desert.

Name: Calbuco Volcano
Description: Located in the Chilean Lake District, the Calbuco volcano can be found at the southeast of Llanquihue Lake and northwest of Chapo Lake. The volcano and the surrounding area are protected within Llanquihue National Reserve and it's a truly beautiful place for hiking and climbing.
Description (with html): Located in the Chilean Lake District, the Calbuco volcano can be found at the southeast of Llanquihue Lake and northwest of Chapo Lake. The volcano and the surrounding area are protected within Llanquihue National Reserve and it's a truly beautiful place for hiking and climbing.

Name: Caleta Gonzalo
Description: Caleta Gonzalo is used as a base from which to explore the Pumalín Douglas Tompkins National Park.
Description (with html): Caleta Gonzalo is used as a base from which to explore the Pumalín Douglas Tompkins National Park.

Name: Caleta Tortel
Description: Caleta Tortel sits on the Rio Baker, with snow capped mountains in the background. A quaint experience, Tortel is essentially a small settlement built on stilts - there are no conventional streets, only raised wooden walkways. It stretches for a couple of kilometres along the shoreline of a cove, sitting amid mountain channels, fjords, estuaries and islands... It's an absolute must if you find yourself in the area. The nearby Steffens and Jorge Montt glaciers can be explored by boat, as can the Isla de los Muertos - the "Island of the Dead" - home to dozens of unnamed graves from the early 20th Century ...and, eerily, nothing else!

Name: Caleta Valdes
Description: A beautiful spot some 77km from Puerto Piramides in Peninsula Valdes (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), Caleta Valdes lies on the coast of Argentina. Made up of a long, pebbled beach, Caleta Valdes is home to Elephant seals who arrive here in August and spend the following months creating their harem of females. Perhaps the most exciting thing about Caleta Valdes is the opportunity to see Orcas (Killer Whales) hunting seals by purposefully beaching themselves in order to catch their prey between September and April.

Name: Caliboro Reserve Winery
Description: Caliboro Reserve Winery is a historic and ambitious winery in the Maule Valley of Chile, known for producing its high-quality "Erasmo" wine from a unique, dry-farmed vineyard on an ancient estate. Owned by Count Francesco Marone Cinzano
Description (with html): Owned by Count Francesco Marone Cinzano

Name: Calvo Fjord
Description: This fjord is a truly specatcular place in which to see huge hanging glaciers coming down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap. The fjord is usually accessed by boat, where passengers disembark onto a Zodiac boat and spend a couple of hours sailing close to the Capitan Constantino, visiting Fernando, Capitan Constantino and Alipio Glaciers amongst others. Find out more about seeing the Calvo Fjord on an adventure cruise in Patagonia >>

Name: Calvo Glacier
Description: One of the glaciers of the Peel Fjord, the impressive Calvo glacier can be found in a small fjord which splits into several arms. As one of the lesser known glaciers and places to visit, this area is a great place to go kayaking and discover new fjords and glaciers. Find out more about visiting this fjord on board an adventure cruise in Patagonia >>

Name: Campamento Britanico
Description: Campamento Britanico is a campsite at the top of the French Valley (Valle Frances), which is used as a base for the few people who climb Las Torres. On the W Trek and Full Circuit, most people trek to this campsite and back, but don't spend a night there. It is around a 30 minute trek from here on to the French Valley Lookout Point, from which there are incredible views of the hanging Glaciar Frances.

Name: Campamento Japones

Name: Campamento La Playita
Description: Literally meaning beach, La Playita is a remote campsite on the rocky shore of Lago Electrico and, with towering peaks on either side, this is a very dramatic spot to camp. There are no facilities here other than a few piles of rocks to provide shelter from the wind. Usually this campsite is used to stop off en route to the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, but there are also other trekking routes to explore in the area. More about Trekking in the Area >>

Name: Camping Seron
Description: Situated in the flatter and more gentle northeastern part of Torres del Paine National Park, Camping Seron is one of the stops on the Full Circuit and is approximately 5 hours north of the entrance at Laguna Armarga and Refugio Torres. It is about a further 6 hours hike from Dickson Valley. Find out more about hiking the Full Circuit in Torres del Paine >>

Name: Campo Canada (5,060m)
Description: The first of the high camps and around 700m above Plaza de Mulas.
Description (with html): The first of the high camps and around 700m above Plaza de Mulas.

Name: Canadon del Rio de las Vueltas
Description: Rio de las Vueltas literally means 'The Meandering River', and it twists and turns through Los Glaciares National Park, past the town of El Chalten. A 6km walk or drive to the South East of Chalten takes you to a view point beside the Rio de las Vueltas Canyon. There are extensive views back along the river to El Chalten and Mount Fitz Roy behind. From here you can also see the interesting rock strata that make up the canyon walls and can often spot low-flying condors.

Name: Cape Horn
Description: Cape Horn, or Cabo de Hornos, is the southernmost headland of the Tierra del Fuego archipelago and many people aim to see it on their visit to the southernmost city in the world, Ushuaia. In fact, certain Patagonian cruises allow you to visit Cape Horn as part of an adventure through the fjords and channels of Southern Patagonia. It's perhaps best known for the treacherous waters which surround it. Owing to gusty winds, huge waves, strong currents and icebergs, a fair few ships have met there end here over the years The Cape has its own small Hornos Island and the Cape itself marks the northern boundary of the Drake Passage, a notoriously rough body of water separating the southernmost tip of Patagonia from Antarctica.

Name: Carlos III Island
Description: Located in the Magellan Strait, Carlos III Island is close by the Francisco Coloane Maritime Park, a protected coastal area of some 67,000 acres, for scientific research. It's here that it's possible to see Humpback whales breaching and playing in the water during a Patagonian Adventure Cruise from December through to April.

Name: Casa Silva Winery
Description: The oldest winery in the Colchagua Valley of Chile, with vineyards dating back to 1892.

Name: Casablanca
Description: The town of Casablanca is located between Santiago and Valparaíso. The Casablanca Valley is one of Chile's most important regions for the production of premium white wine – Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc and Pinot Noir.
Description (with html): The town of Casablanca is located between Santiago and Valparaíso. The Casablanca Valley is one of Chile's most important regions for the production of premium white wine – Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc and Pinot Noir.

Name: Casablanca Volcano
Description: Casablanca is a volcano in the Andes of Los Lagos Region, Chile. It lies approximately 56 miles east of the city of Osorno and host on its slopes the Antillanca ski resort. It's also a popular climbing and hiking destination during the Patagonian season.

Name: Cascada Rucaco
Description: Cascada Rucaco is a small waterfall in the Rucaco River, which you can see when trekking in the mountains of Nahuel Huapi National Park.

Name: Castro
Description: Castro is the largest town on Chiloé island and also the oldest: the conquistador and royal governor of Chile Martín Ruiz de Gamboa founded a settlement on the quiet estuary here in 1567 to serve as a base to conquer the island’s Huilliche people. The town is famous for its shingle-roofed palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), which give it a much more attractive air than when a young Charles Darwin passed through in 183 and judged it a forlorn and depressing town. Today, it’s the island’s thriving capital and an important centre for Chile’s salmon industry.Castro’s most famous attraction today is the Iglesia San Francisco de Castro – one of the 16 wooden Chilote churches that make up the island’s UNESCO World Heritage listing. While many of Chiloé's churches can be rather plain in their beauty thanks to their Jesuit roots, the Franciscan church has an exuberant riot of colour covering its neo-Gothic twin-towered exterior. It was built in 1912 to replace its predecessor which had burned to the ground, and hides its iron frame in brightly painted alerce wood, with buttery yellows offset by mauve and violet details. The interior is plainer, with richly polished wood everywhere. Just south of Castro is a second prominent church, Iglesia Nuestra Señora de Gracia de Nercon , with a tall tower easily spotted from the road. Castro has two diverting museums: the Musei Regional de Castro on the main square, which has fine displays dedicated to the original Huillipihe inhabitants, and the Museo de Arte Moderno de Chiloé , which brings the island’s story up to date by showing off Chiloés burgeoning arts scene. Castro’s Mocupulli airport (code MHC) is 20km north of the town and has daily flights to Santiago, which take just under two hours.
Description (with html):
Castro is the largest town on Chiloé island and also the oldest: the conquistador and royal governor of Chile Martín Ruiz de Gamboa founded a settlement on the quiet estuary here in 1567 to serve as a base to conquer the island’s Huilliche people. The town is famous for its shingle-roofed palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), which give it a much more attractive air than when a young Charles Darwin passed through in 183 and judged it a forlorn and depressing town. Today, it’s the island’s thriving capital and an important centre for Chile’s salmon industry.

Castro’s most famous attraction today is the Iglesia San Francisco de Castro – one of the 16 wooden Chilote churches that make up the island’s UNESCO World Heritage listing. While many of Chiloé's churches can be rather plain in their beauty thanks to their Jesuit roots, the Franciscan church has an exuberant riot of colour covering its neo-Gothic twin-towered exterior. It was built in 1912 to replace its predecessor which had burned to the ground, and hides its iron frame in brightly painted alerce wood, with buttery yellows offset by mauve and violet details. The interior is plainer, with richly polished wood everywhere.

Just south of Castro is a second prominent church, Iglesia Nuestra Señora de Gracia de Nercon, with a tall tower easily spotted from the road.

Castro has two diverting museums: the Musei Regional de Castro on the main square, which has fine displays dedicated to the original Huillipihe inhabitants, and the Museo de Arte Moderno de Chiloé, which brings the island’s story up to date by showing off Chiloés burgeoning arts scene.

Castro’s Mocupulli airport (code MHC) is 20km north of the town and has daily flights to Santiago, which take just under two hours.

Name: Catarpe
Description: Catarpe is a valley and archaeological site located near the town of San Pedro de Atacama in northern Chile. It's a popular destination for tourists visiting the Atacama Desert.
Description (with html): Catarpe is a valley and archaeological site located near the town of San Pedro de Atacama in northern Chile. It's a popular destination for tourists visiting the Atacama Desert.

Name: Catedral de Marmol
Description: The Capillas de Marmol (the Marble Caves), also known as Catderal de Marmol (the Marble Cathedral), is an inredible natural attraction that draws hundreds of visitors every year to the little town of Puerto Tranquilo (from where boats and kayaks can be rented with which to visit). Created by the erosive effect of the blue water of Lago General Carrera lapping at the stone, the Cathedral looks like a beautiful piece of sculpted artwork.

Name: Cerro Aconcagua
Description: Aconcagua is one of the '7 summits' - the highest peak in each continent. In fact it's the highest mountain in both the Western and Southern Hemispheres. And yet, it is accessible to amateurs - fit, strong and resolute amateurs, but amateurs nevertheless. This is your chance to don the crampons and ice axe, feel the exhilaration of climbing above the clouds, and earn the right to say that you've climbed one of the '7 summits'. More info on climbing Mount Aconcagua

Name: Cerro Bandera
Description: Cerro Bandera or Flag Mountain in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego has a well-known reasonably easy trekking route which leads you up the valley to the mountain. From the top you have panoramic views over the town of Puerto Williams and The Beagle Channel. It takes about half a day to trek up and down and once you reach the top of Cerro Bandera it is commonplace to place a stone to show you were there.

Name: Cerro Bastión
Description: See this striking mountain as you make your way along the Rio Manso by raft! At this point along the river, you'll have a fantastic view of Mount Bastión, as you head along a narrow canyon. Reminiscent of Los Cuernos in Torres del Paine due to its colours and shape, Cerro Bastión is located in the beautiful Nahuel Huapi National Park in the Patagonian Lake District of Argentina.

Name: Cerro Benitez
Description: Cerro Benítez is a prominent mountain peak in Chilean Patagonia, located near Puerto Natales, known for its scenic hiking trails that offer panoramic views of the surrounding landscapes, including Lago Sofía, and for its significant archaeological sites with ancient cave paintings, as well as being a prime location for spotting Andean condors. It is also geologically linked to the Cueva del Milodón Natural Monument, which sits on its southern flank.
Description (with html): Mountain located in the Andean Condor

Name: Cerro Carnero
Description: Cerro Carnero (916m) is located in the Los Glaciares National Park. It can be summited on a day trek from Estancia Cristina.
Description (with html): Cerro Carnero (916m) is located in the Los Glaciares National Park. It can be summited on a day trek from Estancia Cristina.

Name: Cerro Castillo
Description: Cerro Castillo is a small farming settlement in southern Chilean Patagonia, not far from the larger town of Puerto Natales. Cerro Castillo is one of the landmarks on many horse riding trips in southern Patagonia as it evokes the 'estancia' lifestyle of this region. The fact that Cerro Castillo lies on the open pampas makes it a great base from which to go horse riding and gives you incredible views of Torres del Paine National Park in the distance. With regard to amenities, there isn't much save for a cafe (which does a very nice lamb soup) and shop with lots of books, clothes and goodies for tourists. The bus from Puerto Natales into Torres del Paine stops here en route. As does the bus from El Calafate, so on some trekking trips into Torres del Paine you can start from Calafate and join your group here at lunchtime, and head directly into the park that afternoon. For example this guided W Trek. More info on getting to Torres del Paine.

Name: Cerro Corner Stone
Description: This mountain takes its name from its location, in the corner of the Paine Grande mountain range. Standing at some 1750 metres, it's one of the overlooked peaks of Torres del Paine but certainly a very impressive mountain. If you're hiking the W Circuit or Full Circuit in Torres del Paine, you're unlikely to get near it, but some operators offer off the beaten track trips which allow you to climb part way up the mountain.

Name: Cerro del Medio
Description: The Cerro del Medio stands at 925m and is located immediately north of Ushuaia in the martial mountains. It probably owes its name to the position in which it is located within the chain of martiales mountains, as it is located in the middle of a circus of slightly higher peaks.

Name: Cerro Donoso
Description: Mount Donoso stands at 1,332m and is visible from the beautiful Rio Serrano in the South of the park. From its lookout, you can see out over Torres del Paine National Park, one of the gems of Patagonia. It's also one of the highlights of many horse riding trips in this area of Patagonia, which allow you to ride like a gaucho across the open pampas.

Name: Cerro Falkner
Description: Cerro Falkner (2350m) is located in Nahuel Napi National Park. The ascent through nire and lenga woods takes about 3 hours and is of a medium-level difficulty. You may see condors, foxes and ducks along the way. On reaching the summit ridge, you will be rewarded with mesmerising views of Villarino and Filo Hua Hun lakes, as well as the snow-capped peak of Lanín Volcano.

Name: Cerro Falso Tonelli
Description: One of the highest peaks surrounding Ushuaia Cerro Falso Tonelli sits at 1,141m above sea level, and can be approached from the south east as a side-route to the Montes Martial trek around Ushuaia. Trekking in Tierra del Fuego >>

Trekking in Tierra del Fuego >>

Name: Cerro Fitz Roy
Description: Cerro Fitz Roy is named after the Captain of the HMS Beagle, who came to Patagonia in 1834 with Charles Darwin. The mountain is a 3,375m towering spire of rock and ice and it is recognised as one of the great challenges by the world's climbing community. It is also known as "Cerro Chalten" or "smoking mountain". Where is it? Fitz Roy sits on the Chile-Argentina border and stands out quite visibly as you fly over the Ice Cap It is situated in Los Glaciares (The Glaciers) National Park, near to El Chalten - it dominates the view from this small town on a clear day How to see it: The best views can be found either by: Hiking to Laguna de los Tres on a day-hike from El Chalten, or trekking the longer Huemul Circuit Or, for the more adventurous, trekking out onto the South Patagonian Ice Cap and viewing it from the west How to get there: A popular trekking destination, it is served by the hotels of El Chalten and the airport in El Calafate, just a four-hour bus ride away Alternatively, consider a trekking tour combining Los Glaciares, in Argentina, and Torres del Paine, in Chile For another way to explore Patagonia, check out our road tours
Description (with html):
Cerro Fitz Roy is named after the Captain of the HMS Beagle, who came to Patagonia in 1834 with Charles Darwin. The mountain is a 3,375m towering spire of rock and ice and it is recognised as one of the great challenges by the world's climbing community. It is also known as "Cerro Chalten" or "smoking mountain".

Where is it?

  • Fitz Roy sits on the Chile-Argentina border and stands out quite visibly as you fly over the Ice Cap
  • It is situated in Los Glaciares (The Glaciers) National Park, near to El Chalten - it dominates the view from this small town on a clear day

    How to see it:

    The best views can be found either by:

    • Hiking to Laguna de los Tres on a day-hike from El Chalten, or trekking the longer Huemul Circuit
    • Or, for the more adventurous, trekking out onto the South Patagonian Ice Cap and viewing it from the west

      How to get there:

      • A popular trekking destination, it is served by the hotels of El Chalten and the airport in El Calafate, just a four-hour bus ride away
      • Alternatively, consider a trekking tour combining Los Glaciares, in Argentina, and Torres del Paine, in Chile
      • For another way to explore Patagonia, check out our road tours

Name: Cerro Gorra Blanca
Description: Gorra Blanca is a 2,900m peak on the eastern edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap , marking the border between Chile and Argentina. Whilst this isn't technically demanding it is a challenging expedition of 5 to 7 days, approaching over glaciers and the Ice Cap itself, with a thousand metre ascent on summit day.The mountain, which was first climbed in 1964, presents great views over the Ice Cap (to the West) and out to Argentina (to the East).Typically, you'd base yourself in El Chalten in Argentina, approach via the Rio Electrico and Piedra del Fraile and use La Playita as your basecamp. From there you head up the Marconi Glacier and over the Marconi Pass.Swoop Founder and CEO, Luke, attempted to climb Gorra Blanca in January 2011, but unfortunately the weather conditions only allowed his group to reach the Marconi Pass.
Description (with html):
Gorra Blanca is a 2,900m peak on the eastern edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap, marking the border between Chile and Argentina. Whilst this isn't technically demanding it is a challenging expedition of 5 to 7 days, approaching over glaciers and the Ice Cap itself, with a thousand metre ascent on summit day.

The mountain, which was first climbed in 1964, presents great views over the Ice Cap (to the West) and out to Argentina (to the East).

Typically, you'd base yourself in El Chalten in Argentina, approach via the Rio Electrico and Piedra del Fraile and use La Playita as your basecamp. From there you head up the Marconi Glacier and over the Marconi Pass.

Swoop Founder and CEO, Luke, attempted to climb Gorra Blanca in January 2011, but unfortunately the weather conditions only allowed his group to reach the Marconi Pass.

Name: Cerro Guido
Description: Cerro Guido is located in Patagonia, Chile. At the base is an estancia, used as a starting point for treks to the summit. On the summit itself is a native Indian burial mound.
Description (with html): Cerro Guido is located in Patagonia, Chile. At the base is an estancia, used as a starting point for treks to the summit. On the summit itself is a native Indian burial mound.

Name: Cerro Huemul
Description: Cerro Huemul is a peak to the South West of El Chalten, close to Lago Viedma. You can trek around this mountain on the Huemul Circuit. This is a trek which starts and ends in El Chalten and takes around four days to complete.
Description (with html): Cerro Huemul is a peak to the South West of El Chalten, close to Lago Viedma. You can trek around this mountain on the Huemul Circuit. This is a trek which starts and ends in El Chalten and takes around four days to complete.

Name: Cerro Lopez
Description: Cerro Lopez is a peak in Nahuel Huapi National Park, which you will pass on the final day of a 4 day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains.
Description (with html): Cerro Lopez is a peak in Nahuel Huapi National Park, which you will pass on the final day of a 4 day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains.

Name: Cerro Mariano Moreno (3,462m)
Description: Cerro Moreno is the third highest peak in Patagonia and is rarely climbed. It is the highest peak in the Cordon Mariano Moreno massif, which lies to the West of the South Patagonian Ice Cap and is accessible only by a lengthy trek over the ice. Trekking the Patagonian Ice Cap >>
Description (with html):
Cerro Moreno is the third highest peak in Patagonia and is rarely climbed.

It is the highest peak in the Cordon Mariano Moreno massif, which lies to the West of the South Patagonian Ice Cap and is accessible only by a lengthy trek over the ice.

Trekking the Patagonian Ice Cap >>

Name: Cerro Mojon Rojo
Description: Cerro Mojon Rojo is a peak close to Mount Fitz Roy in Los Glaciares National Park. This mountain can be climbed in two days and the ascent is semi-technical, including a glacier crossing. From the summit there are spectacular views of the massifs of both Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy. Find out More about Trekking in Los Glaciares >>
Description (with html):
Cerro Mojon Rojo is a peak close to Mount Fitz Roy in Los Glaciares National Park. This mountain can be climbed in two days and the ascent is semi-technical, including a glacier crossing.

From the summit there are spectacular views of the massifs of both Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy.

Find out More about Trekking in Los Glaciares >>

Name: Cerro Navidad
Description: This mountain stands at 2,093 metres in Nahuel Huapi Naitonal Park and is on the route of a 4 day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains.
Description (with html): This mountain stands at 2,093 metres in Nahuel Huapi Naitonal Park and is on the route of a 4 day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains.

Name: Cerro Negro
Description: Cerro Negro stands at 1,970 metres in Nahuel Huapi National Park and is on the route of a 4 day hut-to hut hike through the mountains.
Description (with html): Cerro Negro stands at 1,970 metres in Nahuel Huapi National Park and is on the route of a 4 day hut-to hut hike through the mountains.

Name: Cerro Norte
Description: Mountain peak in Los Glaciares National Park. The area around Cerro Norte is almost uninhabited, there are no communities nearby. Mountainous and hilly terrain around the mountain.
Description (with html): Mountain peak in Los Glaciares National Park. The area around Cerro Norte is almost uninhabited, there are no communities nearby. Mountainous and hilly terrain around the mountain.

Name: Cerro Paine
Description: Standing at some 1,508 metres, Cerro Paine is a notable peak in the east of the Paine massif and one of the few that is accessible to trekkers. If you trek the Full Circuit rather than the W Trek then you'll be able to see Cerro Paine, but you won't be climbing it. You'll need to get off the beaten track with a private guide to climb up here.

Name: Cerro Paine Grande
Description: Cerro Paine Grande is the highest summit of the Cordillera Paine Mountain Range in Torres del Paine National Park. Paine Grande stands at 2750 metres, closely followed by the Cuerno Principal which is said to reach some 2600 metres. You can get great views and photo opportunities of Cerro Paine from across Lago Pehoe and from the area around Refugio Paine Grande, a comfortable hostal on the north-west corner of Lago Pehoe. This is one of the key peaks you will hike around when trekking the Full Circuit or the W Circuit.

Name: Cerro Palo
Description: Cerro Palo is located is Aysén, Chile. It is separated from Cerro Castillo by an alpine valley through which it is possible to trek.
Description (with html): Cerro Palo is located is Aysén, Chile. It is separated from Cerro Castillo by an alpine valley through which it is possible to trek.

Name: Cerro Pelado
Description: An impressive peak in Tierra del Fuego, Cerro Pelado stands at 930 feet and, from its summit, trekkers can look out over the whole of Ushuaia and beyond to the Beagle Channel. The perfect place for a day hike, Mount Pelado is easily accessed from Ushuaia with the help of a local guide. Find out more about trekking in Tuerra del Fuego from Ushuaia.
Description (with html):
An impressive peak in Tierra del Fuego, Cerro Pelado stands at 930 feet and, from its summit, trekkers can look out over the whole of Ushuaia and beyond to the Beagle Channel.

Name: Cerro San Lorenzo
Description: Monte San Lorenzo (3,706m) is a mountain on the Argentinian and Chilean border. The peak was first climbed in 1943. It gained notoriety in 2014 when professional skiers JP Auclair and Andreas Fransson died on its slopes in an avalanche.
Description (with html): Monte San Lorenzo (3,706m) is a mountain on the Argentinian and Chilean border. The peak was first climbed in 1943. It gained notoriety in 2014 when professional skiers JP Auclair and Andreas Fransson died on its slopes in an avalanche.

Name: Cerro San Valentin
Description: At 4058m, this is the highest mountain in Chilean Patagonia. It is also know as Mount San Clemente. It is climbable, but it is a long ascent and is prone to bad weather. We wouldn't recommend it unless you have prior experience of such difficult climbs.
Description (with html): At 4 058m, this is the highest mountain in Chilean Patagonia. It is also know as Mount San Clemente. It is climbable, but it is a long ascent and is prone to bad weather. We wouldn't recommend it unless you have prior experience of such difficult climbs.

Name: Cerro Solo
Description: Cerro Solo stands beside Laguna Torre in the same range as Cerro Torre. The ascent involves crossing a glacier after a difficult climb over loose rock, but this is the least technical climb out of the mountains in this range. From the peak, you get unparalleled views of Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy, as well as the South Patagonian Ice Field.Find out more about Trekking in Los Glaciares or Trekking the Ice Cap.

Name: Cerro Standhardt
Description: Standhardt is located in a four mountain chain, along with Cerro Torre, which is the highest peak in this chain.
Description (with html): Standhardt is located in a four mountain chain, along with Cerro Torre, which is the highest peak in this chain.

Name: Cerro Toco
Description: Cerro Toco is a dormant stratovolcano in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile, known for being one of the most accessible high-altitude peaks in the region and a popular destination for acclimatization hikes with panoramic views of the surrounding volcanoes and salt flats.
Description (with html):
↵↵↵↵↵↵
Cerro Toco

Name: Cerro Torre
Description: Standing close to Cerro Fitz Roy, on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Field, Cerro Torre stands at 3,102 metres. This is one of the highest peaks in the region, and it is a very challenging one to climb. Shrouded in controversial claims of ascent, the first undisputed ascent was in 1974. Where is it? Cerro Torre stands amid the peaks, glaciers, rivers and lagoons of Los Glaciares (The Glaciers) National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site Close to the Patagonian mountain village of El Chalten, and 4 hours by bus from the airport of El Calafate How to see it: Many of the treks from El Chalten take you to view-points of Cerro Torre and Cerro Fitz Roy, including several day-hikes, as well longer routes, such as the Huemul Circuit How to get there: Staying in the nearby town of El Chalten, there are many day-hikes which give you great views of Cerro Torre There is a much more challenging route which takes you up onto the Ice Cap to get much closer to the mountain and see it from a different angle, as part of a demanding expedition You could also make it part of a trekking tour, combining the peaks and glaciers of Los Glaciares with the equally stunning landscapes of Torres del Paine National Park in Chile
Description (with html):
Standing close to Cerro Fitz Roy, on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Field, Cerro Torre stands at 3,102 metres. This is one of the highest peaks in the region, and it is a very challenging one to climb. Shrouded in controversial claims of ascent, the first undisputed ascent was in 1974.

Where is it?

  • Cerro Torre stands amid the peaks, glaciers, rivers and lagoons of Los Glaciares (The Glaciers) National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site
  • Close to the Patagonian mountain village of El Chalten, and 4 hours by bus from the airport of El Calafate

How to see it:

  • Many of the treks from El Chalten take you to view-points of Cerro Torre and Cerro Fitz Roy, including several day-hikes, as well longer routes, such as the Huemul Circuit

How to get there:

  • Staying in the nearby town of El Chalten, there are many day-hikes which give you great views of Cerro Torre
  • There is a much more challenging route which takes you up onto the Ice Cap to get much closer to the mountain and see it from a different angle, as part of a demanding expedition
  • You could also make it part of a trekking tour, combining the peaks and glaciers of Los Glaciares with the equally stunning landscapes of Torres del Paine National Park in Chile

Name: Cerro Tres Reyes
Description: Cerro Tres Reyes is a mountain in Nahuel Huapi National Park, standing at 2,063 metres.
Description (with html): Cerro Tres Reyes is a mountain in Nahuel Huapi National Park, standing at 2,063 metres.

Name: Cerro Vespignani
Description: Located next to Lago del Desierto, to the North of El Chalten, Cerro Vespignani is arguably the best peak in the area which can be climbed in just one day. The climb is not overly technical, and from the top there are magnificient views of the South Patagonian Ice Field.
Description (with html): Located next to Lago del Desierto, to the North of El Chalten, Cerro Vespignani is arguably the best peak in the area which can be climbed in just one day. The climb is not overly technical, and from the top there are magnificient views of the South Patagonian Ice Field.

Name: Cerro Zapata
Description: Cerro Zapata (1590m/5,220ft) is located in Torres del Paine National Park. It is possible to climb to the summit on a 26km day hike from Zapata camp.
Description (with html): Cerro Zapata (1590m/5,220ft) is located in Torres del Paine National Park. It is possible to climb to the summit on a 26km day hike from Zapata camp.

Name: Chaitén
Description: Capital of the Province of Palena, Chaiten is home to an impressive volcano which last erupted in 2008 leading to the evacuation of the city some 6 miles away.
Description (with html): Capital of the Province of Palena, Chaitén is home to an impressive volcano which last errupted in 2008 leading to the evacuation of the city some 6 miles away.

Name: Chaitén Volcano
Description: Chaitén Volcano is located in Pumalín Park in Chile. It is an active volcano surrounded by temperate rainforest and can be visited on a day-hike from Chaitén village.
Description (with html): Chaitén Volcano is located in Pumalín Park in Chile. It is an active volcano surrounded by temperate rainforest and can be visited on a day-hike from Chaitén village.

Name: Chapelco Airport (CPC)
Description: This airport can be used to access the northern part of the Argentinian Lake District around San Martin de los Andes, as well as the fishing lodges and rivers around this area.
Description (with html): This airport can be used to access the northern part of the Argentinian Lake District around San Martin de los Andes, as well as the fishing lodges and rivers around this area.
NEW CUSTOM ADDRESS/WHAT3WORDS: El puente, Callejón de Bello y, San Martín de los Andes, Neuquén, Argentina

Name: Chepu River Valley
Description: The Chepu River Valley is located on the west coast of Chiloé Island.
Description (with html): The Chepu River Valley is located on the west coast of Chiloé Island.

Name: Chile Chico
Description: A small town on the southern shore of the Lago Genereal Carrera, it is one of the largest of the surrounding settlements. Just 4km west of the border with Argentina, it serves as a nice little stop-over when crossing between Chile and Argentina. Crossing the lake by ferry to Puerto Ibanez on the north shore is a lovely experience in the summer sun, as is following the route along the shoreline by car.

Name: Chillán Nuevo volcano
Description: Chillán Nuevo is one of the three main volcanic cones within the Nevados de Chillán Volcanic Complex, an active group of stratovolcanoes in the Andes of the Ñuble Region, Central Chile. This dome complex was formed between 1906 and 1945 and is known for its ongoing volcanic activity. 3,212 m (10,538 ft)

Name: Chiloe Island
Description: Chiloe is a truly unique location. Its vast coastline, wetlands, river systems, forests and fields offer some of the richest bird watching in Southern Chile; even from the 30 minute ferry journey to access the island, you can spot dolphins, penguins and groups of playful sea lions. On arrival on the island you will be met with rolling countryside, dramatic coastal scenery, quiet bays and inlets, and allwith a back drop of the mighty snow peaked Andes. Get off the beaten track for a few days hiking the rugged pacific coast, sea kayak in the peaceful water channels, visit penguin colonies and explore beautiful wooden Jesuit churches on the Eastern Coast. More about Chiloe >>

Name: Chituca Mountain Lodge
Description: Chituca Mountain Lodge is located to the southwest of the Uyuni Salt Flats, on the Bolivian Altiplano.
Description (with html): Chituca Mountain Lodge is located to the southwest of the Uyuni Salt Flats, on the Bolivian Altiplano.

Name: Chonchi
Description: Chonchi is a village port on the coast of Chiloé Island in Chile. Boats sail from here on excursions around the nearby islands of Lemuy, Chelin and Quehui.
Description (with html): Chonchi is a village port on the coast of Chiloé Island in Chile. Boats sail from here on excursions around the nearby islands of Lemuy, Chelin and Quehui.

Name: Chorrillo del Salto
Description: Chorrillo del Salto is a waterfall with a drop of around 20 metres, which can be reached by a 3km walk from El Chalten. The waterfall is hidden in a lenga forest and the area around it is a great place to relax on a fine day. In the winter months, it freezes over completely and is popular with ice climbers.

Name: Circo de los Altares
Description: On the Western side of Cerro FitzRoy this provides relative cover on the edge of the Patagonian Ice Cap.
Description (with html): On the Western side of Cerro FitzRoy this provides relative cover on the edge of the Patagonian Ice Cap.

Name: Clos Apalta Winery
Description: This revolutionary winery is solely dedicated to the production of Casa Lapostolle's world-class icon wine, Clos Apalta. The winery is 100% gravity-fed spanning five levels, three of which are buried into the granite of the Apalta hillside to provide a natural cool temperature environment for cellaring and ageing.

Name: Cochamó
Description: The town of Cochamo is a wonderful base for a range of activities in the area. Mountain biking, trekking and horse riding are great ways to see this verdant region, as you cross rivers, visit waterfalls and ride through dense rainforest on your way up to La Junta Valley. This remote place east of the Reloncaví Estuary holds lots of lakes for kayaking in Cochamo, if you fly in from Puerto Varas or Puerto Montt you can be kayaking on Lake Tagua Tagua only a few hours later. More about Cochamo >>

Name: Cochrane
Description: Cochrane is the base for many adventures into the Aisen region of Chile. It is the provincial capital of Prat Province and one of the main and most comprehensvie supply and service centres to the south of Chile Chico. Tamango National Reserve, designed for the conservation of South Andean Deer, lies nearby and also offers fishing trips and long walks suitable for all ages. For the mountaineers among you, Mt San Lorenzo (3, 706m) - one of the highest peaks in Patagonia, is accessible from the town.

Name: Comau Fjord (Leptepu)
Description: The spot to go to see sea lion colonies in the wild. Jump in a kayak and find yourself literally metres from them. You'll also see snow-capped peaks and lush forests with native trees including the famous Chilean alerce. You'll see plunging waterfalls, granite slopes dropping into the water and get the chance to relax in one of this regions many natural springs.

You'll see plunging waterfalls, granite slopes dropping into the water and get the chance to relax in one of this regions many natural springs.

Name: Confluencia (3,450m)
Description: Camp Confluencia is around a 4 hour hike (normally taken at a very steady pace) from the entrance to the Aconcagua Provincial Park. It's not quite as large as Plaza de Mulas and has fewer services but it's well established with several mess tents and very basic toilet facilities. Confluencia is normally the base for an acclimatisation day to Plaza Francia along the eastern edge of the 10km long Horcones glacier ( Ventisquero Horcones Inferior). From Confluencia the route up to basecamp is via the Horcones valley, and normally an 8-9 hour day.

Name: Conguillio National Park
Description: Conguillío National Park is a stunning national park in the Araucanía Region of Chile, famous for its otherworldly, volcanic landscapes dominated by the active Llaima volcano, ancient forests of "monkey puzzle" trees (araucaria), and beautiful lakes and lagoons formed by lava flows.
Description (with html): Conguillio National Park

Name: Copiapó
Description: This is a major city and a mining hub in the Atacama Desert region of northern Chile, known for its historic mining heritage and as a gateway to the desert's unique landscapes.
Description (with html): This is a major city and a mining hub in the Atacama Desert region of northern Chile, known for its historic mining heritage and as a gateway to the desert's unique landscapes.

Name: Cordillera Baguales
Description: The Cordillera Baguales are lesser-explored range of mountains in Patagonia, Chile. There are stunning views of Torres del Paine from the summit.
Description (with html): The Cordillera Baguales are lesser-explored range of mountains in Patagonia, Chile. There are stunning views of Torres del Paine from the summit.

Name: Cordillera Darwin
Description: The Darwin range lies in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego, and offers the chance to trek in a remote and impressive landscape. The highest mountain in the range is Monte Darwin, which is a challenging peak to climb.
Description (with html): The Darwin range lies in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego, and offers the chance to trek in a remote and impressive landscape. The highest mountain in the range is Monte Darwin, which is a challenging peak to climb.

Name: Cordillera de Sal
Description: The Cordillera de la Sal (Salt Mountain Range) is a unique geological formation near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, composed of salt, clay, and gypsum that have been sculpted by wind and water into surreal, Martian-like landscapes and canyons.
Description (with html): The Cordillera de la Sal (Salt Mountain Range) is a unique geological formation near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, composed of salt, clay, and gypsum that have been sculpted by wind and water into surreal, Martian-like landscapes and canyons.

Name: Cordoba Pass
Description: The Cordoba Pass (1311m) is located on Route 63, between Lake Traful and Lake Filo Hua Hum. It is a popular destination for cyclists.
Description (with html): The Cordoba Pass (1311m) is located on Route 63, between Lake Traful and Lake Filo Hua Hum. It is a popular destination for cyclists.

Name: Coyhaique
Description: Coyhaique is a provincial and regional capital, known for its interesting pentagonal design. It is also key access point into Patagonia and onto the Carretera Austral, the magical route that connects northern Chile to its southern wilderness. The airport at Balmaceda is just 55km away, making this the perfect first stop at which to get your bearings once you land. It's a sizeable city for the region, home to 55 000 people, and has all of the necessities you might expect. Positioned on the confluence of the Simpson and Coyhaique Rivers, it is a great place for fly-fishing.

Name: Cuernos del Paine
Description: Where to find them Torres del Paine National Park, Chile What are they? The Cuernos del Paine or 'Paine horns' is a collective name given to a set of spiky granite peaks in Torres del Paine National Park , all of which stand at over 2000 metres high. The spikes have fittingly sharp names: to the north, the Aleta de Tiburón (Shark's Fin), to the east, from north to south, Fortaleza (Fortress), La Espada (The Sword), La Hoja (The Blade), La Máscara (The Mask), Cuerno Norte (North Horn), and Cuerno Principal (Main Horn).The Cuernos del Paine also lend their name to one of the park's 'refugios' or 'lodges', Refugio and Camping Los Cuernos . How can I see them? The Cuernos are located in the middle of the W Trek, the most popular route for trekking in Torres del Paine National Park. Best views are from the top of Valle Frances, often hiked on day 3 of a traditional W Trek. Find out more about... Hiking in Torres del Paine The W Trek Getting to Torres del Paine
Description (with html):
Where to find them

Torres del Paine National Park, Chile

What are they?

The Cuernos del Paine or 'Paine horns' is a collective name given to a set of spiky granite peaks in Torres del Paine National Park, all of which stand at over 2000 metres high. 

The spikes have fittingly sharp names: to the north, the Aleta de Tiburón (Shark's Fin), to the east, from north to south, Fortaleza (Fortress), La Espada (The Sword), La Hoja (The Blade), La Máscara (The Mask), Cuerno Norte (North Horn), and Cuerno Principal (Main Horn).

The Cuernos del Paine also lend their name to one of the park's 'refugios' or 'lodges', Refugio and Camping Los Cuernos.

How can I see them?

The Cuernos are located in the middle of the W Trek, the most popular route for trekking in Torres del Paine National Park. Best views are from the top of Valle Frances, often hiked on day 3 of a traditional W Trek. 

Find out more about... 

↵
  • Hiking in Torres del Paine
  • The W Trek
  • Getting to Torres del Paine

Name: Cueva de las Manos
Description: The Cueva de las Manas (Cave of the Hands) is one of the most important archaeological sites in South America. The cave paintings date from between 9300 to 3300 years ago and were made by the ancestors of the Tehuelche people. The site was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1999.
Description (with html): The Cueva de las Manas (Cave of the Hands) is one of the most important archaeological sites in South America. The cave paintings date from between 9300 to 3300 years ago and were made by the ancestors of the Tehuelche people. The site was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1999.

Name: Dalcahue
Description: The small coastal town of Dalcahue is one of the best places on Chiloé for handicrafts shopping: its Sunday market attracts artisans from across the island to sell their wares. Woollen goods including jumpers, hats and chunky socks, all hand-dyed with natural pigments make the best souvenirs here. If you can’t make it on a Sunday, a smaller version of the market runs throughout the week. Chile’s 1960 earthquake saw the destruction of most of Dalcahue’s palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), but the town’s most important traditional wooden church survived the tremor. The Iglesia de Nuestra Señora de los Dolores (Church of Our Lady of Sorrows) with its nine-arched facade, octagonal bell tower and interior barrel roof in simple whitewash was built in 1849, and is one of the 16 churches that collectively won Chiloé its UNESCO World Heritage-listed status in 2015. From Dalcahue, it’s possible to take a short ferry trip across the channel to Quinchao Island , where you can visit the equally imposing Iglesia Santa María de Loreto , Chiloés oldest church, built by the Jesuits in 1740.

If you can’t make it on a Sunday, a smaller version of the market runs throughout the week.

Chile’s 1960 earthquake saw the destruction of most of Dalcahue’s palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), but the town’s most important traditional wooden church survived the tremor. The Iglesia de Nuestra Señora de los Dolores (Church of Our Lady of Sorrows) with its nine-arched facade, octagonal bell tower and interior barrel roof in simple whitewash was built in 1849, and is one of the 16 churches that collectively won Chiloé its UNESCO World Heritage-listed status in 2015.

From Dalcahue, it’s possible to take a short ferry trip across the channel to Quinchao Island, where you can visit the equally imposing Iglesia Santa María de Loreto, Chiloés oldest church, built by the Jesuits in 1740.

Name: Death Valley
Description: Death Valley (Valle de la Muerte) is a desert valley near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, known for its surreal, Mars-like landscape of jagged rock formations and massive sand dunes, making it a popular spot for sandboarding and watching the sunset

Name: Diablo Lake and Hill
Description: Diablo Lake and Hill are located in the Los Glaciares region. The trail in this area is in a private reserve and is one of Chalténs lesser-known gems.
Description (with html): Diablo Lake and Hill are located in the Los Glaciares region. The trail in this area is in a private reserve and is one of Chalténs lesser-known gems.

Name: Dickson Valley & Glacier
Description: Dickson Lake and Glacier are found in the northern part of the famous Torres del Paine National Park in Chilean Patagonia. Only 5% of visitors to the park come to see the beauty of this valley, which is visited on the Full Circuit trek of Paine as opposed to the W Circuit, which takes in the highlights of Las Torres, Valle Frances and Glacier Grey. Dickson has a campsite and Refugio for trekkers and bikers, who come this way on guided mountain biking tours. To find out more about visiting Lago Dickson, see our Torres del Paine page.

Name: Dientes de Navarino
Description: The Dientes de Navarino or 'Navarino Teeth' located on Navarino Island in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego, get their name from the formation of these peaks in a semi circle that resembles a jaw full of teeth. The trail was first discovered in the early 1990's by Australian climber and author, Clem Lindenmayer. Find out more about the trek here. The town of Puerto Williams is the main access point for the trek which can be accessed on a flight from Punta Arenas. The town is very small so provisions are best acquired in Punta Arenas.

Name: Easter Island
Description: Monolithic carved human figures stand guard to the majestic Easter Island, where you can experience the natural tropical beauty of beaches, waterfalls, forests and volcanoes. A small town on the island offers peaceful accommodation in a characterful lodge, with gardens filled with hummingbirds and fragrant flowers.

Name: EcoCamp Patagonia
Description: In the heart of Torres del Paine National Park, the Eco Camp is made up of a collection of geodesic domes, designed to minismise its environmental footprint. The domes provide accommodation ranging from comfortable standard domes with shared bathrooms to luxurious suite domes. A good selection of excursions with English speaking guides are on offer. Find out more about Eco Camp Patagonia.

Name: El Bolsón
Description: El Bolson, a bustling tourist town in the Argentinian Lake District is known for its old hippies who came here from Buenos Aires in the 1970s and its local market selling artisan crafts. Located about an hour's drive from the Chilean border, El Bolsón is the closest town to Los Alerces National Park and is found in the southwest of Río Negro Province, Argentina. Although there isn't an infinite number of things to do in the centre of El Bolsón, it is a nice place for a stroll and an ice cream, particularly when the weather is warm during Patagonian summer (Nov-March). El Bolsón is a only 1.5 hour's drive from Bariloche, and is a popular place from which to go trekking, horse riding, fly fishing and kayaking into the surrounding mountains, lakes and rivers.

Name: El Calafate
Description: If you're planning to visit Los Glaciares National Park, you'll almost certainly pass through El Calafate on the shores of Lago Argentino. With a major airport and easy transport links to other destinations in Argentina, El Calafate is the hub for anyone wanting to visit El Chalten and Fitz Roy or the Perito Moreno Glacier. The town is also a 5 hour bus journey from Puerto Natales in Chile, the gateway to Torres del Paine National Park.

Name: El Chaltén
Description: El Chalten is a small trekking town in Los Glaciares National Park. From El Chalten, you can hike straight into the mountains of the Fitz Roy area. Sitting at the foot of Cerro Fitz Roy, which dominates the skyline on a clear day, El Chalten is the base for the top climbers to tackle this peak, as well as many others, and for expeditions onto the South Patagonian Ice Cap. Accommodation options, restaurants, bars and places to rent or buy gear are all good , but communications with the outside world remain very primitive - a blessing for many visitors.

Name: El Paso Leon
Description: El Paso León is a remote and historically significant Mountain Pass located on the border between Chile and Argentina, in the Southern Patagonian Ice Field region. It is a challenging trekking route that offers stunning views of glaciers and pristine Patagonian wilderness, often used by experienced adventurers and as a boundary reference point.
Description (with html): Very remote border crossing.

Name: Ensenada
Description: Ensenada is on the eastern shore of Lago Llanquihue and 47km from Puerto Varas. From here you can climb the nearby Volcan Osorno which dominates the skyline, or visit the waterfalls of the Petrohué river, just 7km away.

Name: Ensenada Bay
Description: A picturesque spot close to Tierra del Fuego National Park, Ensenada Bay offers 'postcard views' over the Beagle Channel with mountains and water as far as the eye can see. Many excursions take you to this area of Tierra del Fuego as part of a day trip to the national park. It's also a popular place to go kayaking as you're likely to see seals and cormorant colonies.

Name: EOLO Lodge
Description: Surrounded by mountains and plains, this remote, upscale, seasonal, all-inclusive hotel is 7km from Lago Argentino lake, and 27km from the nearest town, El Calafate. Airy, upscale suites are TV-free and offer mountain, valley and/or lake views. All have free Wi-Fi. Meals, guided hikes, mountain biking and round-trip transportation from El Calafate are included. Other amenities include a polished restaurant/bar with lake views, a cosy lounge, a TV room and a library. There's also an indoor pool and a sauna. Children age 12 and over are welcome.

This town acts as a gateway to the Los Alerces National Park, which is approximately 30 miles away. Here there are opportunities to take some wonderful boat trips on the lakes or to explore on foot with some lovely walking routes. Find out more about places to go in Argentina >>

Horse riding, trekking, fishing and 4x4 trips are all offered by the estancia.

Name: Estancia Harberton
Description: Estancia Harberton is an old farm situated in Tierra del Fuego on the shore of the Beagle Channel. Although no longer keeping sheep, the estancia still raises cattle alongside providing accommodation for visitors from October to April. The estancia is visited on some boat trips from Ushuaia, and there are guides who give guided tours of the farm and the area's oldest Nature Reserve. Harberton was the first estancia established on the island of Tierra del Fuego in 1886. It was brought here from England by Thomas Bridges, a missionary who had come to evangelise the Yaghan peoples who lived there. Thomas Bridges and his family were the first family to live peacefully (apart from one occurence) amongst the Yaghan and the sixth generation of the family still lives there today.

Name: Estancia Huechahue
Description: Experience the authentic estancia lifestyle of Patagonia in this beautifully rugged and remote setting. The main concern of the estancia is raising cattle and horses, and this is the perfect base for incredible horse-riding experiences. Other activities, including fly fishing, are also on offer here, and at the end of each adventure-filled day you can relax with traditional wine and asado. Find out more about Estancia Huechahue.

Name: Estancia La Quinta
Description: An authentic estancia on the outskirts of El Chalten. If you're looking for an interesting place to stay, with comfortable rooms and huge beds, bright and welcoming dining room and library, plus an out house which is part of the old estancia, you'll find it here. The Halvorsen family that live here are descended from one of the original settlers in Chalten. Find out more and see other hotels in El Chalten.

Name: Estancia Laguna Amarga
Description: Laguna Amarga is one of the best places on earth to observe pumas in the wild. Nowhere else the population density is as high as on this Ranch. Previously it was common practice for the land owners to hunt pumas, in order to avoid that those kill their sheep. Now however, there has grown a new generation on the Estancias, advocating for a tolerant cooperation. Now you can watch the pumas in their natural habitat while on the same Estancia there is being practiced livestock farming, whereupon the sheep are being guarded by livestock guardian dogs, so that they don’t fall prey to the pumas.

Name: Estancia Perales
Description: Estancia Perales, a remote waterside estancia, is almost next to the Glaciar Serrano, a beautiful hanging glacier in the southern part of Torres del Paine National Park. Dominated by the high peaks of the Chacabuco mountain range, some of which are permanently covered in snow and ice, and with views of Cerro Prat to the rear, this is a very special place and a real contrast to some of the scenery inside the Park. The estancia welcomes a variety of guests who arrive here either via Zodiac boat from Puerto Natales or on the 21 de Mayo boat which collects kayakers from further up the Serrano River. The estancia is not only a great place for a lamb asado, it also farms cattle and sheep.

Name: Estancia Puerto Consuelo
Description: Estancia Puerto Consuelo is a historic Patagonian ranch and tourist attraction located near Puerto Natales in Chilean Patagonia. It is notable as the site of the first permanent European settlement in the Ultima Esperanza province, founded by German pioneer Hermann Eberhard, and offers visitors an authentic experience of Patagonian life, including traditional lamb barbecues (asado al palo) and activities like horseback riding along the Eberhard Fjord.

Name: Explora Atacama
Description: Explora Atacama is a luxury, all-inclusive hotel in the town of San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, offering guided explorations into the surrounding desert landscapes and serving as a base for experiencing the region's culture, geography, and astronomy.
Description (with html): Explora Atacama is a luxury, all-inclusive hotel in the town of San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, offering guided explorations into the surrounding desert landscapes and serving as a base for experiencing the region's culture, geography, and astronomy.

Name: Explora El Chaltén
Description: This stunning luxury lodge is nestled in the Los Huemules Reserve to the North of El Chalten and bordering Los Glaciares National Park. Enjoy views of the Electric Valley and the Marconi Glacier in contemporary yet rustic interiors with traditional estancia design influences. The lodge boasts delectable cuisine, a spa and stunning guided excursions.See our page on Explora El Chaltén to find out more.

Description: There are two airports in Buenos Aires: Ezeiza (EZE) is the international airport which you will fly into from abroad; to get a connecting flight down into Patagonia, you then need to transfer to Jorge Newbery (AEP). Find out more about the airports in Buenos Aires.

Name: Frutillar
Description: Frutillar is a very small town found in the Chilean Lake District, near to Puerto Varas. Buses run frequently here from Puerto Montt. Situated on the shores of Lago Llanquihue, Chile's largest lake, there are some opportunities here for kayaking in the Summer Months. It also offers views of the Volcan Osorno.

Name: Futangue Park
Description: Futangue Park is a vast private nature reserve and hotel in the Chilean Lake District, preserving a large portion of the unique Valdivian rainforest and offering over 100 kilometers of exclusive trails for hiking, biking, and exploring its beautiful lakes, waterfalls, and volcanic landscapes.

Name: Geyser del Tatio
Description: Geyser del Tatio is a geothermal field in the Andes Mountains of northern Chile, known for being the highest geyser field in the world and the third largest overall, where visitors can witness spectacular columns of steam erupting from the ground at sunrise.

Description: The Aguila Glacier is found in Tierra del Fuego and is accessed by cruising through Agostini Sound. After disembarking from the boat, an easy walk along the lagoon into which the glacier feeds gives you a closer view of the ice and the surrounding mountains.

Name: Glaciar Geike
Description: Coming down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, Glaciar Geike is reasonably difficult to access by any other means than kayak. This impressive glacier has been retreating for the last few years and doesn't see any signs of slowing down. Find out more about visiting this glacier on our kayaking in Torres del Paine page.

Name: Glaciar Grande
Description: The huge Glaciar Grande is one of the many glaciers in Los Glaciares National Park to come down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap. The glacier, which runs into the pale Laguna Torre, is relatively easily accessible. The trek up to the glacier from El Chalten is an enjoyable one which leads you along the picturesque Rio Fitz Roy, which, like the famous Mount Fitz Roy, is named after the captain of the HMS Beagle on Darwin's voyage through Patagonia. It's possible to don a pair of crampons and ice hike on this impressive glacier, but only with a guide. From here you'll have spectacular views to the north of the long glacial tongue of Glacier Torre and Cerro Torre standing at some 3,102 metres.

Name: Glaciar Los Perros
Description: Glaciar Los Perros descends from the Paine Massif, feeding into Laguna Los Perros in the northern part of Torres del Paine National Park. This area is visited by relatively few people and the glacier can be seen when trekking the Full Circuit of the park.
