Name: Los Alerces National Park
Description: The home of many Alerce trees, and situated in the Andean region of the province of Chubut. The park has a series of lakes, rivers and mountains creating one of the most beautiful parks in Argentina.
Description (with html): The home of many Alerce trees, and situated in the Andean region of the province of Chubut. The park has a series of lakes, rivers and mountains creating one of the most beautiful parks in Argentina.

Name: Los Amigos waterfall
Description: The Los Amigos waterfall is located in Tierra del Fuego and visited on the Torres del Río Chico Basecamp trek.
Description (with html): The Los Amigos waterfall is located in Tierra del Fuego and visited on the Torres del Río Chico Basecamp trek.

Name: Los Cuernos (Lago Nordenskjold)
Description: The 'Cuernos' of Torres del Paine are some of the most impressive peaks in this beautiful national park. Along with the Towers of Paine, The Cuernos are one of the main highlights visited on the W Circuit hike which takes 4-5 days to complete. The Cuernos form a cirque of impressive cliffs at the top of the French Valley. The walls of Cerro Cota 2000 rise sharply to the west. This mountain gets its name from the fact that its highest contour line is about 2,000 m (6,562 ft). Cerro Catedral is named so because its east face resembles a cathedral's facade. To the north stands the granite spire called Aleta de Tiburón or Shark's Fin, to the east, lie La Fortaleza (Fortress), La Espada (The Sword), La Hoja (The Blade), La Máscara (The Mummer), Cuerno Norte (North Horn), and Cuerno Principal (Main Horn). Some of the best photos of Los Cuernos are taken on board the boat across Lake Pehoe, directly beneath Los Cuernos. Find out more about visiting these impressive mountains and trekking in Torres del Paine.

Name: Los Tempanos Lagoon, Queulat
Description: A beautiful lagoon with views of the Hanging Glacier.

Name: Magdalena Island
Description: Located in the Magellan Straits, this island is home to a huge colony of Magellanic penguins who come here to breed, nest and feed throughout the year. A popular spot on many Austral adventure cruises, this island allows you to get up close to the penguins before arriving in Ushuaia, the southernmost city in the world. In the past the island was an essential source of supplies for navigators and explorers, hence the seaside red and white striped lighthouse which still guides today's ships through the Magellan Straits. Find out more about how to see Penguins on this island!

Name: Magellan Straits
Description: This is a highly tidal waterway separating Tierra del Fuego from the mainland. It's possible to cross the straits by ferry, from Punta Arenas to Tierra del Fuego. It's then a 12 hour bus journey down to Ushuaia. Adventure cruises on the Magellan Straits and Beagle Channel afford visitors to this region the chance to get up close to glaciers, waterfalls, penguin colonies and more. The southern tip of Patagonia is home to some incredible spectacles, many of which can only be accessed from the water. Several cruises here also allow you to see Cape Horn. More Information about Cruises in Tierra del Fuego >>

Name: Mallin Colorado
Description: The Mallin Colorado offers comfortable accommodation in cabins overlooking Lago General Carrera. There are options for several excursions around the Carretera Austral, as well as fishing on the Genral Carrera Lake.

Name: Manso River
Description: The Manso River lies in the heart of the Patagonian Lake District on the Argentinian side and is a perfect place for whitewater rafting in Patagonia. This part of the world is lush, green and surrounded by lakes and valdivian jungle. The river itself is a top spot for fishing and even more so, white water rafting. The river starts from Manso Glacier and its waters fill the lakes of Mascardi, Los Moscos, Hess and Steffen. It's split into sections thanks to these lakes which divide it, and each section has a different level of rafting difficulty. The lower section, Manso Inferior, is a class III river which has fast flowing rapids perfect for thrill seekers. Parts of the river there are quite still and a good place to enjoy some swimming too. The lower section Manso Inferior to the Frontier (Chilean border) is a class III/IV river, which makes it even more exciting for adrenaline lovers as it enters a canyon and drops quicker as it flows to the Pacific.

↵

It's split into sections thanks to these lakes which divide it, and each section has a different level of rafting difficulty. The lower section, Manso Inferior, is a class III river which has fast flowing rapids perfect for thrill seekers. Parts of the river there are quite still and a good place to enjoy some swimming too. The lower section Manso Inferior to the Frontier (Chilean border) is a class III/IV river, which makes it even more exciting for adrenaline lovers as it enters a canyon and drops quicker as it flows to the Pacific.

Name: Manso Valley
Description: Calling all adrenaline junkies! The Manso Valley close to Bariloche is the perfect place for white water rafting as it's home to the ferocious Manso River. Even if you're a beginner the river is a great place to raft as its different sections are perfect for different levels of ability.
Description (with html): Calling all adrenaline junkies! The Manso Valley close to Bariloche is the perfect place for white water rafting as it's home to the ferocious Manso River. Even if you're a beginner the river is a great place to raft as its different sections are perfect for different levels of ability.

Name: Marconi Pass
Description: The Marconi Pass is one of only three passes onto the South Patagonian Ice Field . Coming from La Playita campsite at Lago Electrico, you climb 1,000 metres (3,250 feet) up the Marconi Glacier to reach the pass at an altitude of 1,517m above sea level.
Description (with html):
The Marconi Pass is one of only three passes onto the South Patagonian Ice Field.

Coming from La Playita campsite at Lago Electrico, you climb 1,000 metres (3,250 feet) up the Marconi Glacier to reach the pass at an altitude of 1,517m above sea level.

Name: Matamico Lagoon
Description: Matamico Lagoon is located in the Valley of the Lagoons in Tierra del Fuego. Other lagoons in this valley include Chiming Lagoon and Halcón Lagoon.
Description (with html): Matamico Lagoon is located in the Valley of the Lagoons in Tierra del Fuego. Other lagoons in this valley include Chiming Lagoon and Halcón Lagoon.

Name: Matetic Vineyard
Description: A beautiful vineyard set in the heart of the Rosario Valley.
Description (with html): A beautiful vineyard set in the heart of the Rosario Valley

Name: Mendoza
Description: Mendoza is a large city in western Argentina, internationally recognized as the heart of Argentina's wine industry, with hundreds of wineries, and also serves as a major base for mountaineering and outdoor adventures in the nearby Andes Mountains, including climbing the highest peak in the Americas, Aconcagua.
Description (with html): Mendoza is a large city in western Argentina, internationally recognized as the heart of Argentina's wine industry, with hundreds of wineries, and also serves as a major base for mountaineering and outdoor adventures in the nearby Andes Mountains, including climbing the highest peak in the Americas, Aconcagua.

Name: Milodon Cave
Description: The Mylodon Cave is located in Chilean Patagonia, 24km (15 miles) northwest of Puerto Natales and 270km (168 miles) north of Punta Arenas. The cave is located on the side of Cerro Benitez and comprises several caves and a rock formations called Silla del Diablo (Devil's Chair). The cave is notable for the discovery in 1895 of the remains of a giant ground sloth called Mylodon darwinii.
Description (with html): The Mylodon Cave is located in Chilean Patagonia, 24km (15 miles) northwest of Puerto Natales and 270km (168 miles) north of Punta Arenas. The cave is located on the side of Cerro Benitez and comprises several caves and a rock formations called Silla del Diablo (Devil's Chair). The cave is notable for the discovery in 1895 of the remains of a giant ground sloth called Mylodon darwinii.

Name: Mirador Condor
Description: Condor Viewpoint is home to Andean condor and offers superb views of Lake Pehoe, the mountains surrounding the South Patagonian Icefield and Sierra Baguales.
Description (with html): Condor Viewpoint is home to Andean condor and offers superb views of Lake Pehoe, the mountains surrounding the South Patagonian Icefield and Sierra Baguales.

Name: Mirador de los Condores
Description: A very short walk from El Chalten takes you to this viewpoint, from which you will have spectacular views of Cerro Fitz Roy, Cerro Torre and the valley of Rio de las Vueltas. As the name suggests, this is a good location to spot condors, which regularly fly between the Fitz Roy and Vueltas valleys. This is a great place to get panoramic shots of the dramatic landscape, particularly at sunrise.
Description (with html): A very short walk from El Chalten takes you to this viewpoint, from which you will have spectacular views of Cerro Fitz Roy, Cerro Torre and the valley of Rio de las Vueltas. As the name suggests, this is a good location to spot condors, which regularly fly between the Fitz Roy and Vueltas valleys. This is a great place to get panoramic shots of the dramatic landscape, particularly at sunrise.

Name: Mirador del Maestri
Description: This famous viewpoint is located a short walk above Laguna Torre, which can be reached on a day-trek from the town of El Chalten. The viewpoint is named after Cesare Maestri, who claimed to be the first to climb Cerro Torre, although it is thought to be very unlikely that he actually did. As well as views of the dominating peak of Cerro Torre, with Torre Egger and Cerro Standhardt beside it, this viewpoint also gives you spectacular views of Glaciars Grande and Torre, originating high in the mountains and coming down to the laguna below.
Description (with html): This famous viewpoint is located a short walk above Laguna Torre, which can be reached on a day-trek from the town of El Chalten. The viewpoint is named after Cesare Maestri, who claimed to be the first to climb Cerro Torre, although it is thought to be very unlikely that he actually did. As well as views of the dominating peak of Cerro Torre, with Torre Egger and Cerro Standhardt beside it, this viewpoint also gives you spectacular views of Glaciars Grande and Torre, originating high in the mountains and coming down to the laguna below.

Name: Mirador del Pliegue Tumbado
Description: From this viewpoint on the slopes of Loma del Pliegue Tumbado there are stunning views on all sides. As well as a unique perspective on the massifs of Torre and Fitz Roy, there are extensive views over the valleys below them and, in other directions, the Patagonian Steppe and the vast Lago Viedma. The viewpoint can be reached on a day-trek from El Chalten, which takes you up through forest to an area just above 1000 metres, where it is possible to find remains of marine fossils.

As well as a unique perspective on the massifs of Torre and Fitz Roy, there are extensive views over the valleys below them and, in other directions, the Patagonian Steppe and the vast Lago Viedma. The viewpoint can be reached on a day-trek from El Chalten, which takes you up through forest to an area just above 1000 metres, where it is possible to find remains of marine fossils.

Name: Mirador Ferrier
Description: To the west of the park and off all of the main trails, this mirador ('look-out point') offers a unique perspective on the national park and you're unlikely to see more than a handful of people on the trail. It's a fairly steep 2 hour climb, from the parking area next to Hotel Grey, up a well marked path to the top. Up top you are pretty free to rome and find a sheltered spot to admire the Paine Massif, the Grey Glacier and most of the lakes of Torres del Paine National Park's lakes, each a different shade of blue.

Name: Mirador Los Cuernos
Description: Mirador Los Cuernos (The Horns viewpoint) is located on the shore of Lake Nordenskjöld in Torres del Paine.
Description (with html): Mirador Los Cuernos (The Horns viewpoint) is located on the shore of Lake Nordenskjöld in Torres del Paine.

Name: Mirador Torre
Description: A short easy hike from El Chalten takes you to this point, where on a clear day you will have stunning views of Cerro Torre, Fitz Roy and the mountains around them.
Description (with html): A short easy hike from El Chalten takes you to this point, where on a clear day you will have stunning views of Cerro Torre, Fitz Roy and the mountains around them.

Name: Mirador Upsala
Description: Mirador Upsala is located near to Refugio Upsala, in the Los Glaciares National Park. It is a viewpoint for Glacier Upsala.
Description (with html): Mirador Upsala is located near to Refugio Upsala, in the Los Glaciares National Park. It is a viewpoint for Glacier Upsala.

Name: Mitico Puelo Lodge
Description: Stopping off at the Mitico Puelo Lodge makes crossing the Andes between Chile and Argentina a particularly special experience. The lodge is small and secluded - it is inaccessible by road - and the staff provide excellent service. Led by friendly and experienced guides, the excursions on offer help you make the most of the beautiful landscape of the Lake District, whether by foot, bike, horse or kayak. >>> Find out more about Mitico Puelo Lodge

Name: Moat outpost
Description: Moat outpost is located on the Mitre Peninsula in Tierra del Fuego at the end of Ruta J. The buildings here are the property of the Argentine Coastguard. Treks along the Mitre peninsula often start/finish here.
Description (with html): Moat outpost is located on the Mitre Peninsula in Tierra del Fuego at the end of Ruta J. The buildings here are the property of the Argentine Coastguard. Treks along the Mitre peninsula often start/finish here.

Name: Mocho and Choshuenco volcanoes
Description: The Mocho-Choshuenco volcanic complex comprises two prominent stratovolcanoes, Mocho (2,422 m) and Choshuenco (2,415 m), located in the Los Ríos Region of the Chilean Andes. They are an active, ice-clad volcanic system known for their scenic beauty within the Mocho-Choshuenco National Reserve, offering opportunities for hiking, climbing, and winter sports.
Description (with html):
2415 m (Choshuenco)

2422 m (Mocho)

Name: Mocopulli Airport, Castro (MHC)
Description: Mocopulli Airport (MHC) is the primary airport serving the city of Castro and the entire Chiloé Island in Chilean Patagonia. It serves as the main aerial gateway for visitors traveling to this unique island destination.
Description (with html): Mocopulli Airport (MHC) is the primary airport serving the city of Castro and the entire Chiloé Island in Chilean Patagonia. It serves as the main aerial gateway for visitors traveling to this unique island destination.

Name: Montañas Fjord
Description: Cruising down this fjord you'll see 5 glaciers, including Glaciars Herman, Bernal, Alsina and Paredes. The fjord is long and narrow and, as the name suggests, surrounded by mountains.
Description (with html): Cruising down this fjord you'll see 5 glaciers, including Glaciars Herman, Bernal, Alsina and Paredes. The fjord is long and narrow and, as the name suggests, surrounded by mountains.

Name: Monte Susana
Description: Monte Susana is located 4 miles/6.5km west of Ushuaia, just off the Ruta 3 highway. It's a popular area for hiking and horse riding.
Description (with html): Monte Susana is located 4 miles/6.5km west of Ushuaia, just off the Ruta 3 highway. It's a popular area for hiking and horse riding.

Name: Montes Winery
Description: In December 2004, Montes inaugurated the new winery at Apalta. The investment totaled over U$ 7 million with a storing capacity of 2,300,000 litres. A cellar that becomes a qualitative production leap for one of the most applauded Montes red wines: Montes Alpha and the Ultra-Premium Montes Alpha M and Montes Folly in addition to the recently launched Purple Angel.
Description (with html): In December 2004, Montes inaugurated the new winery at Apalta.  The ↵investment totaled over U$ 7 million with a storing capacity of ↵2,300,000 litres.  A cellar that becomes a qualitative production leap ↵for one of the most applauded Montes red wines: Montes Alpha and the ↵Ultra-Premium Montes Alpha M and Montes Folly in addition to the ↵recently launched Purple Angel.

Name: Montevideo
Description: Montevideo is Uruguay's capital city and home to one of South America's most important ports. It overlooks the Río de la Plata, the largest river/estuary (depending on who you ask) in the world. Among a host of historical buildings and cultural offerings, tango shows included, other points of interest are Independence Square, the Old Town, the port market, and the Arts District. The closet airport is Carrasco International Airport, a 40 minute drive from the city.
Description (with html): Montevideo is Uruguay's capital city and home to one of South America's most important ports. It overlooks the Río de la Plata, the largest river/estuary (depending on who you ask) in the world. Among a host of historical buildings and cultural offerings, tango shows included, other points of interest are Independence Square, the Old Town, the port market, and the Arts District. The closet airport is Carrasco International Airport, a 40 minute drive from the city.

Name: Moon Valley
Description: This valley is full of rocky formations and its surface is covered with a layer of salt, so that it resembles the surface of the Moon. Here you can find Las Tres Marias, which are statues made of salt.
Description (with html): This valley is full of rocky formations and its surface is covered with a layer of salt, so that it resembles the surface of the Moon. Here you can find Las Tres Marias, which are statues made of salt.

Name: Mount Castillo
Description: Cerro Castillo is Spanish for "Castle Peak", and you can certainly see why - the jagged outcrops of rock make it look like the fort you always dreamed of playing in as a child! It is 2 675m high and can be climbed along two main routes.
Description (with html): Cerro Castillo is Spanish for "Castle Peak", and you can certainly see why - the jagged outcrops of rock make it look like the fort you always dreamed of playing in as a child! It is 2 675m high and can be climbed along two main routes.

Name: Mount Darwin
Description: Located in the Chliean part of Tierra del Fuego, Mount Darwin forms part of the Cordillera of the Andes Mountain Range and is famous for being the highest peak in the region, towering in this wild and vast land at 2,488 metres (8,163 ft). Mount Darwin was given its name by the captain of HMS Beagle, Robert FitzRoy in order to commemorate Darwin's 25th birthday on 12th February 1834. Mount Darwin is a challenging peak to climb and is best attempted well into Patagonian summer, from December to March.
Description (with html):
Located in the Chliean part of Tierra del Fuego, Mount Darwin forms part of the Cordillera of the Andes Mountain Range and is famous for being the highest peak in the region, towering in this wild and vast land at 2,488 metres (8,163 ft).

Mount Darwin was given its name by the captain of HMS Beagle, Robert FitzRoy in order to commemorate Darwin's 25th birthday on 12th February 1834. Mount Darwin is a challenging peak to climb and is best attempted well into Patagonian summer, from December to March.↵

Name: Mount Tronador (Pampa Linda Village)
Description: Cerro Tronador , standing at 3,491m, is the highest mountain in the Lake District region around San Carlos de Bariloche. Tronador means 'thunderer' and that really is the sound you hear on approach, as ice calves off the glaciers into a natural amphitheatre below. With a day hike from Bariloche you can get up close to its glaciers. It's also possible to climb Tronador; this is a 3 day expedition, summitting on Day 2, and using the Meiling mountain hut on the first and second nights. There are actually a few different peaks on Tronador and for introductory/intermediate trips you'd tackle the 'Pico Argentino' at 3,187m. Tronador lies in the heart of Nahuel Huapi National Park, and is accessed via Pampa Linda, a short drive from San Carlos de Bariloche. It is also the source of the Manso River, one of the top white water rafting rivers in the region.

Name: Mt Bettinelli
Description: Mt Bettinelli (868m) is located on Isla Navarino in Chilean Patagonia. Trekkers can camp at its base and climb to the summit.
Description (with html): Mt Bettinelli (868m) is located on Isla Navarino in Chilean Patagonia. Trekkers can camp at its base and climb to the summit.

Name: Mt Carabajal
Description: Mt Carabajal is located around 10 miles/15km west of Ushuaia, off the Ruta 3 highway. Hiking to the summit of this mountain, and visiting Laguna Turquesa en route, is one of the best day hikes you can do from Ushuaia.
Description (with html): Mt Carabajal is located around 10 miles/15km west of Ushuaia, off the Ruta 3 highway. Hiking to the summit of this mountain, and visiting Laguna Turquesa en route, is one of the best day hikes you can do from Ushuaia.

Name: Neff Glacier
Description: Fed by the North Patagonian Ice Cap the Neff Glacier is one of the more accessible in the region. It is the fifth largest of the Northern Ice Field's glaciers How to see it: Road Trips Although realtively accessible, Neff's location in Aisen means that it isn't amid the main travel hotspots of Torres del Paine and Los Glaciares. That is no bad thing, hoewever: take a roadtrip along the Carreera Austral - Chile's famous highway that runs the spine of Chile - and enjoy the Glacier all to yourself. Ski-Touring For those with some experience, take on the glaciers of the Norh Patagonian Ice Field with your trusted pair of skiis. Ice-Hiking Alternatively, don your crampons and ice-axe and take to Neff Glacier, crossing it as part of a broader tour of Aysen's glaciers. More Details >>

Name: Neuquen
Description: This city is the Capital of the Province of Neuquen in Argentina found in the north of Patagonia, and it is situated at the origin of the River Negro. With a population of 265,000 it is the largest city in Patagonia. It's nearby airport serves most of patagonia including San Carlos de Bariloche, Buenos Aires and Ushuaia.

↵

Name: Neuquen Airport (NQN)
Description: This airport lies in the extreme North of Patagonia, deep in the Patagonian Steppe. It became a more popular chouice when Bariloche airport was closed in 2011 due to a volcanic ash cloud. There are several flights each day from Buenos Aeres.
Description (with html): This airport lies in the extreme North of Patagonia, deep in the Patagonian Steppe. It became a more popular chouice when Bariloche airport was closed in 2011 due to a volcanic ash cloud. There are several flights each day from Buenos Aeres.

Name: Noi Indigo Patagonia
Description: A spa hotel in Puerto Natales based on the Last Hope Sound. Spacious modern rooms, with filling breakfast and the icing on the cake; sauna, massage rooms, jacuzzis and loungers. Find out more and other hotels in Puerto Natales.
Description (with html): A spa hotel in Puerto Natales based on the Last Hope Sound. Spacious modern rooms, with filling breakfast and the icing on the cake; sauna, massage rooms, jacuzzis and loungers. Find out more and other hotels in Puerto Natales.
NEW CUSTOM ADDRESS/WHAT3WORDS: Ladrilleros 105, Puerto Natales

Name: Oggioni Pass
Description: The Oggioni Pass offers a semi-technical route out of the Ascencio Valley and into the Dickson valley area in the north of Torres del Paine national park. It's a tough trek, very much off-the-beaten-track, and only for those up for a challenge. From one of our treks through this pass: The trek leads us 'off trail', up and over steep slopes, showing us views of Torres del Paine National Park that few people see. We push forward through thick forest, crossing wild creeks, and up rocky steep slopes. You should be in very good physical condition for this pass: able to hike long distances, uphill and downhill, with keen mental strength and sense of determination to resist tough elements like strong winds and frozen rain or snowfall (even in the summer). Most of the crossing is along moraine and snow (depending on how much snow this area has received in the last winter). For more info see: trekking the Oggioni Pass and other Torres del Paine treks off-the-beaten-track.

Name: Panguipulli
Description: Panguipulli is a town in the heart of the Chilean Lake District, on the northwestern tip of Lake Panguipulli . It sits at the centre of the Seven Lakes Circuit , a notably pretty road route that runs past Lakes Calafqué, Pellaifa, Neltume, Pirehueico, Riñihue, Pullinque, and Panguipulli lakes. The modern town was only founded in the 1940s, but the region itself has been occupied for far longer: Panguipulli means ' Puma hill ' in the Mapudungun language of the original Mapuche inhabitants. Tourists visit Panguipulli for its proximity to the Huilo-Huilo Biological Reserve , as well as the word-class whitewater rafting on the nearby Fuy River , whose rapids are interspersed with a series of dramatic waterfalls. The town also has a noted gastronomic scene, and is famous for its honey, cheese and cider. Panguipulli is 145km (two hours) south of Temuco and its airport, 75km (90 minutes) from Pucón and 235km (three hours) north of Puerto Varas. The latter road in particular is very scenic. The town also offers international connections to Argentina . From nearby Puerto Fuy, a ferry runs along to Lake Pirihueico to the international border at Filo Hua Hum pass, from where a road takes you alongside Lake Lacar to San Martín de los Andes.

Name: Paraíso de la Montaña cabins
Description: The Paraíso de la Montaña cabins are visited on an overnight stop on the Puntiagudo trek. They are located near Lake Rupanco.
Description (with html): The Paraíso de la Montaña cabins are visited on an overnight stop on the Puntiagudo trek. They are located near Lake Rupanco.

Name: Paraty
Description: Paraty is a historic colonial town on Brazil's Green Coast, famous for its beautifully preserved pedestrian-only cobblestone streets, vibrant houses with colorful doors, and a bay dotted with over 65 islands, making it a popular spot for boat tours, hiking to waterfalls, and exploring the surrounding Atlantic rainforest. It is located in the state of Rio de Janeiro, between the cities of Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo.
Description (with html): Paraty is a historic colonial town on Brazil's Green Coast, famous for its beautifully preserved pedestrian-only cobblestone streets, vibrant houses with colorful doors, and a bay dotted with over 65 islands, making it a popular spot for boat tours, hiking to waterfalls, and exploring the surrounding Atlantic rainforest. It is located in the state of Rio de Janeiro, between the cities of Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo.

Name: Parque Nacional Alerce Andino
Description: Situated in the Chilean Lake District, Alerce Andino is home to more than 50 stunning lakes. With 20,000 hectares of Alerce Forests, there is plenty of nature and scenery to discover. A lovely spot for some day hiking in the Lake District. More about the Lake District >>

Name: Parque Pumalin
Description: In the Chilean Lake District, Parque Pumalin's temperate rainforests are home to a wide variety of flora and fauna. Its main attraction, however, is its spectacular fjords, and the park is a great destination for kayaking.
Description (with html): In the Chilean Lake District, Parque Pumalin's temperate rainforests are home to a wide variety of flora and fauna. Its main attraction, however, is its spectacular fjords, and the park is a great destination for kayaking.

Name: Paso 5 Hermanos
Description: This Pass crosses the 'Fiver Brothers' Mountain Range in Tierra del Fuego. Hiking through the pass is certainly a challenge due to strong winds and the snow which usually covers the pass and its surrounding mountains. For this reason, it's definitely better to trek this route with a guide. The challenge is all worth it though for the views of the impressive mountains all around you. If you're up for a challenge, find out more about Trekking Tierra del Fuego or it's southernmost city, Ushuaia.

Name: Paso Beban
Description: Paso Beban is a high Mountain Pass in the Sierra Valdivieso mountain chain of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. It is a challenging and remote location, popular with experienced hikers and mountaineers, and is known for its beautiful, untouched Patagonian landscapes. It is a key point on multi-day trekking routes in the area and is not a place with a conventional address.

It is a challenging and remote location, popular with experienced hikers and mountaineers, and is known for its beautiful, untouched Patagonian landscapes. It is a key point on multi-day trekking routes in the area and is not a place with a conventional address.

Name: Paso Brecha Negra
Description: This is a Mountain Pass in Nahuel Huapi National Park.
Description (with html): This is a Mountain Pass in Nahuel Huapi National Park.

Name: Paso de la Oveja
Description: Paso de la Oveja (Sheep Pass) is a challenging Mountain Pass located in the remote wilderness of the Fuegian Andes in Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. It is often encountered as part of multi-day trekking routes, offering adventurers stunning, rugged Patagonian landscapes. Mountain Pass at 831m above Ushuaia.
Description (with html): Mountain Pass at 831m above Ushuaia

Name: Paso de las Agachonas
Description: This is a Mountain Pass at 1354 metres on Loma del Pliegue Tumbado. Climbing up to the pass gives you stunning panoramic views of Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy. It is highly recommended that you are accompanied by a guide for this trek. Find out more about Trekking in Los Glaciares >>
Description (with html):
This is a Mountain Pass at 1354 metres on Loma del Pliegue Tumbado. Climbing up to the pass gives you stunning panoramic views of Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy.

It is highly recommended that you are accompanied by a guide for this trek.

Find out more about Trekking in Los Glaciares >>

Name: Paso del Cuadrado
Description: The Paso del Cuadrado is located in the Los Glaciares region. Trek up to this pass through the Eléctrico Valley. The views from the pass are spectacular and include the major peaks of Cerro Torre, Polone and Fitz Roy.
Description (with html): The Paso del Cuadrado is located in the Los Glaciares region. Trek up to this pass through the Eléctrico Valley. The views from the pass are spectacular and include the major peaks of Cerro Torre, Polone and Fitz Roy.

Name: Paso del Viento
Description: Paso del Viento, or the 'windy pass', is found on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap, at 1,428m above sea level . The pass is a 2 day hike from the town of El Chalten. Read about a customer's trek to Paso del Viento on our blog.
Description (with html):
Paso del Viento, or the 'windy pass', is found on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap, at 1,428m above sea level. The pass is a 2 day hike from the town of El Chalten.

↵

Read about a customer's trek to Paso del Viento on our blog.

Name: Paso Guillaumet
Description: Crossing Paso Guillaumet brings you amazingly close to the eastern face of Mount Fitz Roy and also gives you a great view back down the length of Glaciar Piedras Blancas to Rio Blanco. The trek includes crossing Piedras Blancas glacier and some low difficulty rock climbing. It is a physically demanding trek which requires the use of some technical equipment.
Description (with html): Crossing Paso Guillaumet brings you amazingly close to the eastern face of Mount Fitz Roy and also gives you a great view back down the length of Glaciar Piedras Blancas to Rio Blanco. The trek includes crossing Piedras Blancas glacier and some low difficulty rock climbing. It is a physically demanding trek which requires the use of some technical equipment.

Name: Paso Huemul
Description: Paso Huemul is a Mountain Pass at 1,005 metres, which lies on the Huemul Circuit in Los Glaciares National Park. From here there are spectacular views of Glaciar Viedma falling into the lake of the same name. Close by, Paso Huemul Campsite can be used by those trekking this circuit, which takes a few days to complete.
Description (with html): Paso Huemul is a Mountain Pass at 1,005 metres, which lies on the Huemul Circuit in Los Glaciares National Park. From here there are spectacular views of Glaciar Viedma falling into the lake of the same name. Close by, Paso Huemul Campsite can be used by those trekking this circuit, which takes a few days to complete.

Name: Paso John Garner (Grey Glacier)
Description: Where to find it Torres del Paine National Park, Chile What is it? Paso John Garner (the John Garner Pass) is one of the most famous passes on the Full Circuit Trek. It is an awe-inspiring pass, with views out across the Grey Glacier and, on a clear day, out across the South Patagonian Ice Cap itself. It's also one of the highest points you are likely to trek to in Torres del Paine, at an altitude of around 1,200 metres above sea level. How can I see it? On the Full Circuit multi-day hike you approach the pass from Laguna Los Perros, from the east. It's very windy up there, and the descent down to the Grey Glacier is one of the toughest sections of the whole trek. However, the views are incredible, and if you've got the time and stamina to do the Full Circuit then this view alone makes it worthwhile. Find out more about... The Full Circuit hike Hiking in Torres del Paine Torres del Paine National Park
Description (with html):
Where to find it

Torres del Paine National Park, Chile

What is it?

Paso John Garner (the John Garner Pass) is one of the most famous passes on the Full Circuit Trek. It is an awe-inspiring pass, with views out across the Grey Glacier and, on a clear day, out across the South Patagonian Ice Cap itself. It's also one of the highest points you are likely to trek to in Torres del Paine, at an altitude of around 1,200 metres above sea level.

How can I see it?

On the Full Circuit multi-day hike you approach the pass from Laguna Los Perros, from the east.

↵

It's very windy up there, and the descent down to the Grey Glacier is one of the toughest sections of the whole trek. However, the views are incredible, and if you've got the time and stamina to do the Full Circuit then this view alone makes it worthwhile.

Name: Patagonia Austral Marine National Park
Description: The marine park in Chubut region is one of the newest of its kind in Argentina and was set up to protect the many different types of wildlife that breed in this area including the Southern Right Whale.
Description (with html): The marine park in Chubut region is one of the newest of its kind in Argentina and was set up to protect the many different types of wildlife that breed in this area including the Southern Right Whale.

Name: Patagonia Camp
Description: Located just outside Torres del Paine National Park on the shore of Lago Toro, Patagonia Camp is a collection of luxury 'yurts'. These tented domes are all equipped with hot running water, heating, their own bathroom and a private terrace with views over the lake towards the Paine massif. >>Find out more and check availability for Patagonia Camp

Name: Patagonia Park
Description: Set to become part of the Patagonia National Park, Parque Patagonia (or Patagonia Park) is 200,000 acres of grasslands protecting rare and endangered species. The park welcomes visitors to enjoy the undisturbed scenery, hike the trails and explore the land. Find out more >>

Name: Peel Fjord
Description: As one of the most visited parts of Bernardo O'Higgins National Park, the Peel Fjord is a serene and pristine place to visit, with lots of wildlife, nature and a whole host of sparkling glaciers. The best way of getting here is by boat or kayak. To find out more about trips that visit this fjord in the wilderness, see kayaking in Torres del Paine.

Name: Peninsula Quetrihue
Description: Peninsula Quetrihué is a peninsula in Nahuel Huapi National Park, Argentina, that is home to the world-famous Arrayanes Forest, a unique forest of cinnamon-colored myrtle trees that is a major tourist attraction, reachable by boat from Bariloche or by a 12km trail from Villa La Angostura.
Description (with html):
↵↵↵↵↵↵
Peninsula Quetrihue
↵

Name: Península Valdés
Description: This idyllic UNESCO World Heritage site is a mecca for wildlife enthusiasts from around the globe, due to it's abundance of nature's largest and most diverse marine wildlife . The Valdes Peninsula itself is a unique formation stretching some 1,400 square miles along the Atlantic coast of Argentina. A global conservation site for some of the largest marine mammals , who take advantage of it's two unique sheltered inlets .The Valdes Peninsula is home to some of the ocean's largest mammals, including the Southern Right Whale, the Orca, and the Southern Elephant Seal. It is also home to an array of other marine life including dolphins and sea lions, as well as some interesting land dwellers such as guanacos, foxes, hares and armadillos, and a vast selection of bird species.We recommend that you explore Valdes' coves and beaches by sea kayaking over 1-3 days, cycling its sand dunes and heading out in a small boat to get within a few metres of a giant whale and its calf. From there take a couple of days to drive around the Peninsula and walk amongst a Magellanic penguin colony and see a beach full of basking Elephant seals. Peninsula Valdes >>
Description (with html):
This idyllic UNESCO World Heritage site is a mecca for wildlife enthusiasts from around the globe, due to it's abundance of nature's largest and most diverse marine wildlife. The Valdes Peninsula itself is a unique formation stretching some 1,400 square miles along the Atlantic coast of Argentina. A global conservation site for some of the largest marine mammals, who take advantage of it's two unique sheltered inlets.

The Valdes Peninsula is home to some of the ocean's largest mammals, including the Southern Right Whale, the Orca, and the Southern Elephant Seal. It is also home to an array of other marine life including dolphins and sea lions, as well as some interesting land dwellers such as guanacos, foxes, hares and armadillos, and a vast selection of bird species.

We recommend that you explore Valdes' coves and beaches by sea kayaking over 1-3 days, cycling its sand dunes and heading out in a small boat to get within a few metres of a giant whale and its calf. From there take a couple of days to drive around the Peninsula and walk amongst a Magellanic penguin colony and see a beach full of basking Elephant seals.

Peninsula Valdes >>

Name: Penitentes
Description: An Argentine ski resort 3-4 hours from Mendoza and close to the Chilean border. It takes its name from Cerro Penitentes which sits behind. In the winter it's a popular spot for local skiiers but come November it becomes the launch pad for mountaineering expeditions up Aconcagua. The fresh nervous faces of climbers coming in wondering if they'll make it, and the inevitably sunburned and haggard faces of those who have come down from their adventure and looking forward to that first cold beer. There are a number of hotels in the little village (and not much else) - we know and recommend Ayelen. From here it's a 10-15 minute drive to the entrance to the Aconcagua Provincial Park, and then a 4 hour hike up to Confluencia Camp a staging post en route to basecamp at Plaza de Mulas.

Name: Peñón Blanco
Description: This remote and pristine islet in the fjords of Chilean Patagonia's coast are visited en route to Puerto Montt on the cruise itinerary from Puerto Natales. A beautiful place to stop and look out at turquoise waters, mountains and trees as far as the eye can see.

Name: Perez Cruz Vineyard
Description: Planted in the 90’s and according to the natural conditions of the Maipo Alto for excellence red wines production, Pérez Cruz chose the best varieties for its terroir. The 140 hectares of vines are planted with Cabernet Sauvignon (70%), Carmenere (10%), Merlot (5%), Syrah (5%), Cot or Malbec (5%) and Petit Verdot (5%).

Name: Perito Moreno Glacier
Description: Perito Moreno is arguably the most famous glacier in Patagonia, and for good reason. Winding for 20 miles down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, it is a truly enormous glacier. Moreover, it is one of only a handful of advancing glaciers in the world, growing by approximately 2 metres per day. Where is it? Perito Moreno glacier lies in Los Glaciares National Park ("Glaciers National Park") in Argentinian Patagonia 80km from El Calafate, which has one of Patagonia's largest airports How to see it: You can visit visit Perito Moreno in all sorts of ways, whether from the comfort of its viewing platforms or on a more adventurous ice-hike on the glacier itself A popular destination for travellers, it is served by the hotels of El Chalten and the airport in El Calafate Incorporate it into a broader exploration of Los Glaciares and Patagonia
Description (with html):
Perito Moreno is arguably the most famous glacier in Patagonia, and for good reason. Winding for 20 miles down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, it is a truly enormous glacier. Moreover, it is one of only a handful of advancing glaciers in the world, growing by approximately 2 metres per day.

Where is it?

  • Perito Moreno glacier lies in Los Glaciares National Park ("Glaciers National Park") in Argentinian Patagonia
  • 80km from El Calafate, which has one of Patagonia's largest airports

How to see it:

  • You can visit visit Perito Moreno in all sorts of ways, whether from the comfort of its viewing platforms or on a more adventurous ice-hike on the glacier itself
  • A popular destination for travellers, it is served by the hotels of El Chalten and the airport in El Calafate
  • Incorporate it into a broader exploration of Los Glaciares and Patagonia

Name: Petrohue
Description: The scenic port of Petrohue sits at the westernmost tip of Lake Todos los Santos in the Chilean Lake District, where the turquoise waters drain into the mouth of the Petrohue river. The tiny town is dwarfed by the the mighty snowcapped peak of the Osorno volcano which stands as its backdrop. The port is stop on the Cruce Andino road-and-ferry route from Puerto Varas to Bariloche in Argentina, as well as being home to the Petrohue Lodge hotel.Following the road southwest from the town along the river takes you to the beautiful Saltos de Petrohue , a waterfall where turquoise waters charge dramatically through old lava channels. It is possible to arrange kayaking trips downstream of the falls. The fast-flowing river is also well-stocked with trout, making it an ideal flyfishing location. The Petrohue Lodge on the shore of the lake is the perfect place to base yourself and arrange either of these activities, along with canyoning, rafting and hiking. Petrohue is just under an hours' drive from Puerto Varas. From here, the ferry to Peulla departs daily in the middle of the morning. The trip takes around two hours, with the boat returning in the afternoon.
Description (with html):
The scenic port of Petrohue sits at the westernmost tip of Lake Todos los Santos in the Chilean Lake District, where the turquoise waters drain into the mouth of the Petrohue river. The tiny town is dwarfed by the the mighty snowcapped peak of the Osorno volcano which stands as its backdrop. The port is stop on the Cruce Andino road-and-ferry route from Puerto Varas to Bariloche in Argentina, as well as being home to the Petrohue Lodge hotel.

Following the road southwest from the town along the river takes you to the beautiful Saltos de Petrohue, a waterfall where turquoise waters charge dramatically through old lava channels. It is possible to arrange kayaking trips downstream of the falls. The fast-flowing river is also well-stocked with trout, making it an ideal flyfishing location. The Petrohue Lodge on the shore of the lake is the perfect place to base yourself and arrange either of these activities, along with canyoning, rafting and hiking. 

Petrohue is just under an hours' drive from Puerto Varas. From here, the ferry to Peulla departs daily in the middle of the morning. The trip takes around two hours, with the boat returning in the afternoon.

Name: Pia Glacier
Description: Where to find it Tierra del Fuego, along the Chilean Patagonia coast between Ushuaia and Punta Arenas. The mountains are in the Darwin Range. What is it? Pia Glacier is breathtakingly big. It tumbles down from the mountains into the sea in a secluded corner of the Chilean Fjords, and is one of the highlights of 'Glacier Alley'. Sit on the shore long enough and you're bound to hear it creaking and groaning as the ice moves. If you're lucky, you'll even catch the huge splash as the ice calves from the frozen wall, and crashes into the water. How can I see it? You can visit this glacier on board an adventure cruise from Punta Arenas to Ushuaia, which explores the fjords and channels of Tierra del Fuego, including the Strait of Magellan and Cape Horn. On arriving at the glacier, you'll have the opportunity to head out in a zodiac boat to get the full impact of the glacier's enormity, before disembarking for a hike to a panoramic viewpoint. Our top trips that visit Pia Glacier Find out more about... Adventure cruises in Tierra del Fuego Tierra del Fuego Glaciers in Patagonia

Where to find it

Tierra del Fuego, along the Chilean Patagonia coast between Ushuaia and Punta Arenas. The mountains are in the Darwin Range.

Sit on the shore long enough and you're bound to hear it creaking and groaning as the ice moves. If you're lucky, you'll even catch the huge splash as the ice calves from the frozen wall, and crashes into the water.

Name: Piedra del Fraile
Description: This is a really charming campsite in the Electrico valley to the north of Mount Fitz Roy. The "piedra" refers to a huge boulder once dumped in the valley by the glacier. The boulder provides a good degree of shelter in what is otherwise a very exposed valley on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap.The campsite itself is small (maybe 10-15 pitches) and relatively basic (a few shelters for cooking and basic washrooms), but there's a great hut with a wood-burning stove (and a very content dog), and it serves surprisingly good pizzas and cold beers.Piedra del Fraile could either be a destination in itself or a nice stopping off point en route to the Marconi Pass and the Ice Cap , the Polllone valley or Piedra Negra. It takes about 2-3 hours to get here from the Rio Electrico bridge (a 30 min transfer from El Chalten).
Description (with html):
This is a really charming campsite in the Electrico valley to the north of Mount Fitz Roy. The "piedra" refers to a huge boulder once dumped in the valley by the glacier. The boulder provides a good degree of shelter in what is otherwise a very exposed valley on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap.

The campsite itself is small (maybe 10-15 pitches) and relatively basic (a few shelters for cooking and basic washrooms), but there's a great hut with a wood-burning stove (and a very content dog), and it serves surprisingly good pizzas and cold beers.

Piedra del Fraile could either be a destination in itself or a nice stopping off point en route to the Marconi Pass and the Ice Cap, the Polllone valley or Piedra Negra.

↵

It takes about 2-3 hours to get here from the Rio Electrico bridge (a 30 min transfer from El Chalten).

Name: Piedra Parada
Description: Argentina's Piedra Parada is a free standing rock in Chubut. The name has gained particular recognition in the climbing world, largely due to the many climbing routes located in the nearby canyon, although there is also some climbing on The Piedra. The closest small town is Gualjaina and major town is Esquel

Name: Plaza Argentina (4,198m)
Description: Base camp on the quieter eastern side of Aconcagua
Description (with html): Base camp on the quieter eastern side of Aconcagua

Name: Plaza de Mulas (4,367m)
Description: Plaza de Mulas acts as basecamp for most ascents of Aconcagua, especially the normal route. It's a very well established camp with a range of services including wifi, hot showers and even cold beers. At the peak of the climbing season it can support as many as 200 people. Conditions can vary dramatically with some climbing parties finding it hot and dusty, whereas others arrive to six inches of snow. The camp is filled with people either arriving from Confluencia, setting out on an acclimatisation climb to Cerro Bonnete, or resting before heading to Camp Canada en route to their summit attempt. On most expeditions you'll spend a total of around 5-6 days here, so it starts to feel pretty familiar.

Name: Plaza Francia (4,228m)
Description: Campsite for the highly technical and challenging southern face of Cerro Aconcagua. Also acts as a great acclimatisation day from Confluencia Camp for those attempting the Normal Route of Aconcagua. The hike from Confluencia takes you along the Horcones Glacier (Ventisquero Horcones Inferior) and allows you to climb a height comparable with basecamp at Plaza de Mulas.

Name: Porcelana Bay
Description: Immersed in lush Valdivian forest, Porcelana Bay is a must see for any kayaking fantatic, looking to experince the wild side of Patagonia and spend an hour or two in its warm, relaxing springs.

Name: Porvenir

Name: Posada Quelat
Description: This lodge, formerly called Fiordo Quelat EcoLodge, lies between a fjord and a rainforest, and it is a peaceful base for exploring Quelat National Park.

Name: Pucon
Description: The lakeside town of Pucon sits beside the Villarica Volcano in the Chilean Lake District. From here you can summit the volcano to see its smoking crater and magnificent views along a chain of snow-capped volcanoes, and in the nearby Huerquehue National Park, trails lead through ancient forests of monkey-puzzle trees, mirror lakes and waterfalls. If you fancy rafting or kayaking, then staying in one of Pucon’s wooden lodges gives you plenty of opportunity for this too. More about Pucon >>

Name: Puerto Aguirre
Description: Puerto Aguirre is a small fishing port. It is possible to spend some time exploring this quaint village on an aventure cruise.

Name: Puerto Almanza
Description: Puerto Almanza is a small village in Tierra del Fuego on the northern shore of the Beagle Channel. It lies about 3km west from another settlement on the channel called Almirante Brown and its almost opposite to the Chilean port of Puerto Williams.It's mostly a resting point for fishermen and is an access point to some local ranches in Tierra del Fuego when roads are cut due to bad weather.

It's mostly a resting point for fishermen and is an access point to some local ranches in Tierra del Fuego when roads are cut due to bad weather.

Name: Puerto Aysén
Description: Puerto Aysén is a port city in the Aysén Region of southern Chile, situated on the Aysén River, and is a key hub for tourism and trade, serving as a gateway to the Carretera Austral and the surrounding Patagonian fjords and national parks.
Description (with html): Puerto Aysén is a port city in the Aysén Region of southern Chile, situated on the Aysén River, and is a key hub for tourism and trade, serving as a gateway to the Carretera Austral and the surrounding Patagonian fjords and national parks.

Name: Puerto Bandera
Description: Puerto Bandera is located in the Los Glaciares National Park. Boats depart here for the Perito Moreno Glacier, Estancia Cristina and Glacier Upsala.

Description: Puerto Bertrand sits within easy access of many attractions - Lago General Carrera and its Marble Cathedral; Neff Falls where Rio Baker and Neff meet; Lago Cochrane, and Valle Chacabuco.

Name: Puerto Deseado

Name: Puerto Edén
Description: Puerto Edén is a channel near to Puerto Natales in Chilean Patagonia, which connects to the Seno Ultima Esperanza, or 'Last Hope Sound'. The cruise from Puerto Natales passes this way en route to Puerto Montt, visiting the fjords and canals of this pristine area.

Puerto Edén is a channel near to Puerto Natales in Chilean Patagonia, which connects to the Seno Ultima Esperanza, or 'Last Hope Sound'.

↵

The cruise from Puerto Natales passes this way en route to Puerto Montt, visiting the fjords and canals of this pristine area.

Name: Puerto Fuy
Description: Puerto Fuy is a small port at the North Western end of the Pirihueico lake. You can take a ferry down to the other end of the lake at Puerto Pirihueico, which lies very close to the Argentinian border.
Description (with html): Puerto Fuy is a small port at the North Western end of the Pirihueico lake. You can take a ferry down to the other end of the lake at Puerto Pirihueico, which lies very close to the Argentinian border.

Name: Puerto Guadal
Description: Puerto Guadal is a small tourist town on the south-west edge of Lage General Carrera that is becoming increasingly popular thanks to the Carretera's construction. The area around the lake enjoys a sunny microclimate that makes the lake even prettier.
Description (with html): Puerto Guadal is a small tourist town on the south-west edge of Lage General Carrera that is becoming increasingly popular thanks to the Carretera's construction. The area around the lake enjoys a sunny microclimate that makes the lake even prettier.

Name: Puerto Ibanez
Description: Puerto Ibanez lies on the northern shores of Lago General Carrera close to where the Rio Ibanez joins it. It serves as a border crossing point into Argentina as well as a port for ferries across the Lake to Chile Chico on the southern shore.
Description (with html): Puerto Ibanez lies on the northern shores of Lago General Carrera close to where the Rio Ibanez joins it. It serves as a border crossing point into Argentina as well as a port for ferries across the Lake to Chile Chico on the southern shore.

Name: Puerto Iguazú
Description: Puerto Iguazú is a border-town in the province of Misiones, Argentina. The world-famous Iguazú Falls are only 18km (11 miles) away from the town.
Description (with html): Puerto Iguazú is a border-town in the province of Misiones, Argentina. The world-famous Iguazú Falls are only 18km (11 miles) away from the town.

Name: Puerto Madryn
Description: A pretty town on the eastern coast of Argentina, part of Peninsula Valdes. The wildlife here is truly abundant, if you kayak or take a boat ride out to see, you'll come across killer whales, sea lion colonies and back on land you can walk through a penguin reserve. The nearest airport is that of the Welsh town, Trelew, with regular flights to and from Buenos Aires.
Description (with html): A pretty town on the eastern coast of Argentina, part of Peninsula Valdes. The wildlife here is truly abundant, if you kayak or take a boat ride out to see, you'll come across killer whales, sea lion colonies and back on land you can walk through a penguin reserve. The nearest airport is that of the Welsh town, Trelew, with regular flights to and from Buenos Aires.

Name: Puerto Montt
Description: Puerto Montt is the capital of Chile’s Los Lagos region, and serves as one of the major entry points to the Chilean Lake District and Chiloé island, as well as cruises through the Llanquihue Archipelago to the epic landscapes of Chile's northern fjords. It’s set in a spectacular location on the Reloncaví Sound, fringed with richly forested mountains, but the city itself is very much a working port: most travellers quickly transit the city to make the short hop to the pretty adventure hub of Puerto Varas, a quick 30 minute drive away, or to Vicente Pérez Rosales National Park to climb Osorno volcano.The city’s no-frills atmosphere is underlined by the fact that it was levelled by an earthquake in 1960, almost completely destroying the alpine architecture beloved by the German colonists who founded the town in 1853. The Catedral de Puerto Montt , built in alerce wood with a copper dome three years after the town was established, is the city’s oldest building. The city is built on Mapuche territory, but human habitation here stretches back farther than almost anywhere in the whole of the Americas. At nearby Monte Verde , archaeological remains including hearths, butchered animal remains and even a human footprint were uncovered in 1975 dating back around 18,500 years – a discovery that pushed back the earliest arrival of people on the South American continent by 1000 years. Puerto Montt’s Tepual airport (code PMC) is just 16km west of the town and is served by both LAN and Sky Airlines. From here you can fly to Santiago in just two hours, or south to Punta Arenas to access Torres del Paine National Park. If you want to take the scenic route to Torres del Paine, Puerto Montt is also the departure port for the four day/three night Navimag ferry to Puerto Natales, sailing through Chile’s spectacular fjords. There are no direct ferries from here to Chiloé island. Instead, you must drive 62km south on the mainland to Pargua to catch the car ferry to Chacao. Allow around three hours to transit from Puerto Montt to Ancud on Chiloé, including the 30 minute ferry ride. If you’re driving, the coastal road south from the port is considered to be the starting point for Chile’s famous Carretera Austral.
Description (with html):
Puerto Montt is the capital of Chile’s Los Lagos region, and serves as one of the major entry points to the Chilean Lake District and Chiloé island, as well as cruises through the Llanquihue Archipelago to the epic landscapes of Chile's northern fjords. It’s set in a spectacular location on the Reloncaví Sound, fringed with richly forested mountains, but the city itself is very much a working port: most travellers quickly transit the city to make the short hop to the pretty adventure hub of Puerto Varas, a quick 30 minute drive away, or to Vicente Pérez Rosales National Park to climb Osorno volcano.

The city’s no-frills atmosphere is underlined by the fact that it was levelled by an earthquake in 1960, almost completely destroying the alpine architecture beloved by the German colonists who founded the town in 1853. The Catedral de Puerto Montt, built in alerce wood with a copper dome three years after the town was established, is the city’s oldest building.

The city is built on Mapuche territory, but human habitation here stretches back farther than almost anywhere in the whole of the Americas. At nearby Monte Verde, archaeological remains including hearths, butchered animal remains and even a human footprint were uncovered in 1975 dating back around 18,500 years – a discovery that pushed back the earliest arrival of people on the South American continent by 1000 years.

Puerto Montt’s Tepual airport (code PMC) is just 16km west of the town and is served by both LAN and Sky Airlines. From here you can fly to Santiago in just two hours, or south to Punta Arenas to access Torres del Paine National Park.

If you want to take the scenic route to Torres del Paine, Puerto Montt is also the departure port for the four day/three night Navimag ferry to Puerto Natales, sailing through Chile’s spectacular fjords.

There are no direct ferries from here to Chiloé island. Instead, you must drive 62km south on the mainland to Pargua to catch the car ferry to Chacao. Allow around three hours to transit from Puerto Montt to Ancud on Chiloé, including the 30 minute ferry ride.

If you’re driving, the coastal road south from the port is considered to be the starting point for Chile’s famous Carretera Austral.

Name: Puerto Montt, El Tepual Airport (PMC)
Description: Puerto Montt Airport is officially known as El Tepual International Airport (PMC) and serves as the main gateway to Chile's Lake District and Northern Patagonia.
Description (with html): Puerto Montt Airport is officially known as El Tepual International Airport (PMC) and serves as the main gateway to Chile's Lake District and Northern Patagonia.
NEW CUSTOM ADDRESS/WHAT3WORDS: 5480000 Puerto Montt, Los Lagos, Chile

Name: Puerto Natales
Description: Puerto Natales sits on the edge of the Last Hope Sound (Ultima Eperanza Fjord) and is the gateway to Torres del Paine, in Chilean Patagonia. It lies 247km north of Punta Arenas (Chilean Patagonia's main airport), and 147km from Torres del Paine National Park. Founded in 1911 it was once a key port for the sheep and wool industry, but its main industry is now tourism and it is well set up to support people heading into Torres del Paine National Park. There are a range of accommodation options available, from backpacker hostels to luxury lodges and spas. Find Hotels in Puerto Natales >>In terms of preparations for trekking in Torres del Paine you'll find everything you need here. Shops sell camping equipment, including gas cannisters, and other gear. There is even a North Face shop. However, prices are often higher than in the UK.If you have a spare day then the Cueva de Milodon and the Visitor Centre are worth a visit.

Find Hotels in Puerto Natales >>

In terms of preparations for trekking in Torres del Paine you'll find everything you need here. Shops sell camping equipment, including gas cannisters, and other gear. There is even a North Face shop. However, prices are often higher than in the UK.

If you have a spare day then the Cueva de Milodon and the Visitor Centre are worth a visit.

Name: Puerto Natales Airport (PNT)
Description: Located at the gateway to Torres del Paine, one could assume that Puerto Natales airport would be one of the busiest airports in the area. However, with its sporadic flights, out-of-town location, and complete shut down over winter, Puerto Natales airport receives only a fraction of Torres del Paine's visitors every year. With many more options available, this small airport invariably loses out to reliable public buses and the larger, more comfortable Punta Arenas airport.

Name: Puerto Piramides
Description: Puerto Piramides is a small town on the Peninsula Valdes, within the Nature Reserve and UNESCO World Heritage Site. A small seaside place, from Piramides you can go kayaking out in the bay and around Golfo Nuevo and go whale watching to see Humpback and Orca whales from December to March.
Description (with html): Puerto Piramides is a small town on the Peninsula Valdes, within the Nature Reserve and UNESCO World Heritage Site. A small seaside place, from Piramides you can go kayaking out in the bay and around Golfo Nuevo and go whale watching to see Humpback and Orca whales from December to March.

Name: Puerto Raul Marin Balmaceda
Description: A small village of about 300 inhabitants, Puerto Raul Marin Balmaceda sits on an island in the delta of the Rio Palena. A wonderful location, it lies amid the sands and mountains where Chile meets the Pacific Ocean.
Description (with html): A small village of about 300 inhabitants, Puerto Raul Marin Balmaceda sits on an island in the delta of the Rio Palena. A wonderful location, it lies amid the sands and mountains where Chile meets the Pacific Ocean.

Name: Puerto Toro
Description: Puerto Toro is a very small pier for boats and kayaks, allowing people to explore the Serrano Glacier, at the northern end of the Last Hope Sound.
Description (with html): Puerto Toro is a very small pier for boats and kayaks, allowing people to explore the Serrano Glacier, at the northern end of the Last Hope Sound.

Name: Puerto Tranquilo
Description: A small tourist town, Chileans flock to Puerto Tranquilo for their summer holidays, but it is barely open outside of these peak months. The popularity of the town results from its Marble Caves, also known as the Marble Cathedral (capillas de marmol or catedral de marmol, in Spanish). Located on the shores of Lago General Carrera, into which the Rio Tranquilo feeds, the town is close enough to the Caves for you to visit by boat, or even by kayak.
Description (with html): A small tourist town, Chileans flock to Puerto Tranquilo for their summer holidays, but it is barely open outside of these peak months. The popularity of the town results from its Marble Caves, also known as the Marble Cathedral (capillas de marmol or catedral de marmol, in Spanish). Located on the shores of Lago General Carrera, into which the Rio Tranquilo feeds, the town is close enough to the Caves for you to visit by boat, or even by kayak.

Name: Puerto Varas
Description: Puerto Varas sits on the shores of Lago Llanquihue, the largest lake in the Chilean Lake District. The conical 2,650 metre high Osorno Volcano rises from the lake on the opposite shore. The inhabitants of this area of Chile are an interesting fusion of the indigenous Mapuche people, German settlers from the 1850's and people of colonial Spanish decent, which makes the food, architecture and history very different from Southern Patagonia. While staying here, you can visit the nearby emerald waterfalls, hike to the summit of the Osorno Volcano (a day hike), visit the enchanting Chiloe island or kayak on the Petrohue river. More about Puerto Varas >>

Name: Puerto Williams
Description: Puerto Williams is located in Tierra del Fuego, Patagonia, on Isla Navarino facing the Beagle Channel and is the gateway to the famous Dientes de Navarino trek. The town increased in size as a Chilean naval base and now has grown to include several small supermarkets, a handful of restaurants, a bakery, bar and a museum. Puerto Williams is sometimes considered the southernmost city in the world, a title that is disputed by the larger Ushuaia, located on the opposite, northern side of the Beagle Channel in Argentinian territory. Daily flights run from Punta Arenas to Puerto Williams throughout the year.There's a secluded all-inclusive lodge called the Lakutaia that's a perfect base if you'd prefer to explore from comfort.
Description (with html):
Puerto Williams is located in Tierra del Fuego, Patagonia, on Isla Navarino facing the Beagle Channel and is the gateway to the famous Dientes de Navarino trek. 

The town increased in size as a Chilean naval base and now has grown to include several small supermarkets, a handful of restaurants, a bakery, bar and a museum. Puerto Williams is sometimes considered the southernmost city in the world, a title that is disputed by the larger Ushuaia, located on the opposite, northern side of the Beagle Channel in Argentinian territory. 

Daily flights run from Punta Arenas to Puerto Williams throughout the year.

There's a secluded all-inclusive lodge called the Lakutaia that's a perfect base if you'd prefer to explore from comfort.

Name: Puerto Williams Airport (WPU)
Description: A small landing strip only for light to medium-sized aircraft. Flights are daily from Punta Arenas throughout the year and they are run by a local operator called DAP Airlines.
Description (with html): A small landing strip only for light to medium-sized aircraft. Flights are daily from Punta Arenas throughout the year and they are run by a local operator called DAP Airlines.
NEW CUSTOM ADDRESS/WHAT3WORDS: Aeropuerto Guardiamarina Zañartu, Puerto Williams, XII Región de Magallanes y de la Antártica Chilena, Chile

Name: Puesto Laguna 3 de Abril outpost
Description: Puesto Laguna 3 de Abril outpost is located near the lake of the same name. It's used as an overnight stop on a trip from Estancia Nibepo Aike.
Description (with html): Puesto Laguna 3 de Abril outpost is located near the lake of the same name. It's used as an overnight stop on a trip from Estancia Nibepo Aike.

Name: Pumalin National Park
Description: Along the northern half of the Carretera Austral, Pumalin National Park lies between Hornopiren and Chaiten. It can be accessed by road from either of these towns, by boat through Caleta Gonzalo, or from Argentina via the Paso de Menendez. Pumalin was designated by the government as a nature sanctuary in 2005 and is Chile's largest private nature reserve. There are many trails for hiking and grounds for camping amid untouched Valdivian temperate rainforest that is home to thousands of species and sub-species of flora and fauna, as well as some of the last remaining Alerce trees (one of the oldest species on Earth!). The Park is accessible by car from Chaiten and by ferry from Hornopiren, docking at Caleta Gonzalo at the very centre of the Park.
Description (with html):
Along the northern half of the Carretera Austral, Pumalin National Park lies between Hornopiren and Chaiten.  It can be accessed by road from either of these towns, by boat through Caleta Gonzalo, or from Argentina via the Paso de Menendez.

↵

Pumalin was designated by the government as a nature sanctuary in 2005 and is Chile's largest private nature reserve. There are many trails for hiking and grounds for camping amid untouched Valdivian temperate rainforest that is home to thousands of species and sub-species of flora and fauna, as well as some of the last remaining Alerce trees (one of the oldest species on Earth!). The Park is accessible by car from Chaiten and by ferry from Hornopiren, docking at Caleta Gonzalo at the very centre of the Park.

Name: Puñihuil Penguin Colony
Description: Puñihuil Penguin Colony in Chiloé is the only place in the world where Humboldt and Magellanic penguins nest side by side. The colony is found on three islets around around 27 kilometres southwest of the Gulf of Ancud. Tours to the colony are by small boat: It is not permitted to land on the colony, which was declared a national monument (Monumento Natural Islotes de Puñihuil) in 1999. The penguins live at sea for half the year, but arrive on the islets in October to breed. Chicks tend to hatch around January , in time for the colony to return to sea near the end of March . Puñihuil is only one of several locations to see penguins around Patagonia. Embarking on an adventure cruise around the Magellan Straits and Tierra del Fuego is another popular way to see penguins, or you can take a trip to Peninsula Valdes on the east coast of Argentina, where penguin spotting can be combined with whale-watching.
Description (with html):
Puñihuil Penguin Colony in Chiloé is the only place in the world where Humboldt and Magellanic penguins nest side by side. The colony is found on three islets around around 27 kilometres southwest of the Gulf of Ancud. Tours to the colony are by small boat: It is not permitted to land on the colony, which was declared a national monument (Monumento Natural Islotes de Puñihuil) in 1999.

The penguins live at sea for half the year, but arrive on the islets in October to breed. Chicks tend to hatch around January, in time for the colony to return to sea near the end of March.

Puñihuil is only one of several locations to see penguins around Patagonia. Embarking on an adventure cruise around the Magellan Straits and Tierra del Fuego is another popular way to see penguins, or you can take a trip to Peninsula Valdes on the east coast of Argentina, where penguin spotting can be combined with whale-watching.

Name: Punta Arenas
Description: Established in 1848, Punta Arenas is the capital of the Magallan Province in southern Chilean Patagonia. It is believed that the town was named 'Sandy Point' by a British sea captain called John Byron, who sailed to Patagonia and claimed to have seen giants inhabiting the land. The name was later changed to the Spanish Punta Arenas . Find out h ow to get from Ushuaia to Punta Arenas. Gateway to Torres del Paine Many travellers visiting Torres del Paine National Park fly to Punta Arenas airport (Carlos Ibáñez del Campo International (PUQ)), which lies around 13 miles north of Punta Arenas and serves Chilean Patagonia. The main airlines operating here are LAN Chile and Sky Airline, which offer regular flights from Santiago and Puerto Montt. Once in Punta Arenas, travellers then take the 3-hour bus journey directly to Puerto Natales, a small town just outside Torres del Paine. Puerto Natales is known for its beautiful fjord, the Seno Ultima Esperanza which is perfect for kayaking. Punta Arenas is a good place to relax and prepare for your W Trek or Full Circuit trek in Torres del Paine with a reasonable range of hotels and restaurants. Adventure Cruises As a major sea port, Punta Arenas also acts as a departure point for Patagonia cruises . There are several options, including: Cruises through the Chilean fjords between Punta Arenas and are a fantastic way of either arriving at the trekking heart of Patagonia, or of departing for the north after a W Trek or Full Circuit trek Cruises to Ushuaia, Tierra del Fuego and Cape Horn offer an incredible way of exploring the Magellan Straits sailed by Darwin and getting up close to Magellanic penguins, hanging glaciers and the wild and remote landscape loved by adventurous trekkers. Accommodation It is common when travelling through Punta Arenas to need overnight accommodation, either due to the timing of flights and cruises or simply to break up your journey. We have shortlisted a selection of recommended hotels to make it easier for you to find the place that best fits your needs and budget.

It is believed that the town was named 'Sandy Point' by a British sea captain called John Byron, who sailed to Patagonia and claimed to have seen giants inhabiting the land. The name was later changed to the Spanish Punta Arenas. Find out how to get from Ushuaia to Punta Arenas.

↵

The main airlines operating here are LAN Chile and Sky Airline, which offer regular flights from Santiago and Puerto Montt. Once in Punta Arenas, travellers then take the 3-hour bus journey directly to Puerto Natales, a small town just outside Torres del Paine. Puerto Natales is known for its beautiful fjord, the Seno Ultima Esperanza which is perfect for kayaking.

↵

Punta Arenas is a good place to relax and prepare for your W Trek or Full Circuit trek in Torres del Paine with a reasonable range of hotels and restaurants.

↵

Adventure Cruises

↵

As a major sea port, Punta Arenas also acts as a departure point for Patagonia cruises.  There are several options, including:

Name: Punta Arenas Airport (PUQ)
Description: Nearest major airport to Torres del Paine National Park and three hours south of Puerto Natales. You can also get from Punta Arenas to Ushuaia on Tierra del Fuego via a dramatic 12 hour bus journey. Daily flights from Santiago, and from Puerto Montt. Flights to the Falkland Islands leave from here every Saturday.

Name: Punta Conos
Description: This beautiful and secluded beach can be found on Peninsula Valdes in the province of Chubut in Argentina. 'Conos', meaning cones, refers to the cone-like hillocks in the area. Conos is unlike many other beaches, in that it is rich with the fossils of local sea life dating back millions of years. A fantastic place for kayaking, Conos is one of the many top spots in a kayaking trip in the area. Find out more about kayaking in Patagonia.

Name: Punta Del Este
Description: Punta del Este is a world-renowned, glamorous beach resort city and peninsula located on the Atlantic coast of southeastern Uruguay. Often called the "Monaco" or "St. Tropez of South America," it is famous for its stunning beaches, vibrant nightlife, luxury hotels, casinos, and upscale dining, attracting a mix of international tourists and celebrities.
Description (with html): Punta del Este is a world-renowned, glamorous beach resort city and peninsula located on the Atlantic coast of southeastern Uruguay. Often called the "Monaco" or "St. Tropez of South America," it is famous for its stunning beaches, vibrant nightlife, luxury hotels, casinos, and upscale dining, attracting a mix of international tourists and celebrities.

Name: Punta Delgada
Description: Punta Delgada, at the southern tip of Peninsula Valdes is home to one of the biggest sea lion colonies in South America and the beach is exclusive to customers at the Hotel Faro Punta Delgada. This beautiful spot is one of the many points of interest along the coast on the Peninsula and can be reached by car via a drive of about 2 hours from Puerto Piramides.

This beautiful spot is one of the many points of interest along the coast on the Peninsula and can be reached by car via a drive of about 2 hours from Puerto Piramides.

Name: Punta Leopardos
Description: Just 20 miles from the stunning San Rafael Glacier in the pristine region of Aysen, Punta Leopardos is one of the stops during a 5-6 day trip along the southern Chilean fjords and inlets. The area itself is very peaceful and tranquil, with quiet waters, trees and birds. Find out more about Adventure cruises in Patagonia >>

Name: Punta Loma
Description: The nature reserve of Punta Loma is located just outside Puerto Madryn. It is a popular place for spotting wildlife.
Description (with html): The nature reserve of Punta Loma is located just outside Puerto Madryn. It is a popular place for spotting wildlife.

Name: Punta Norte
Description: Punta Norte at the very northern tip of Peninsula Valdes is around 77 kilometres from Puerto Piramides, the main town on the Peninsula. In Punta Norte is home to a multitude of Elephant seals and Magellanic penguins that live here throughout the year and in great number between December and April (breeding season). This part of the Peninsula is usually best seen by car, and can be reached along the Ruta 30 before driving on the paved roads (with a speed limit of 60km per hour). After seeing Punta Norte, you may want to take the route along the coast south to Caleta Valdes a lagoon formed by a solid 30-kilometer-long bar spreading from North to South and home to a huge colony of Elephant seals and a fantastic place to watch Orcas (Killer whales) hunt seals from February to April. Find out more about visiting Peninsula Valdes >>

Name: Punta Piramides

Punta Piramides is just one of the landmarks you could visit during a kayaking trip on the Peninsula. Find out more about visiting Peninsula Valdes >>

Name: Punta Tehuelche
Description: This remote lighthouse is found on the Peninsula Valdes in the province of Chubut in Argentina. Peninsula Valdes attracts thousands of tourists each year keen to jump in boats to go whale watching. If you're a more adventurous type, you may want to visit this beautiful region by kayak, as you'll get up close to the whales and paddle alongside sea lion colonies. Find out more about kayaking in Patagonia.
